No oxygen sensor on the old cat disconnected? Needs exhaust system.
No spark? That things slowly becoming a handful.
I worked for Cadillac as a district service manager when that car was introduced. In pre-release service meetings, it was well-known from the very beginning, that the 8/6/4 was planned to be a one-year-only engine. The big problem was the early Delco electronics. The MAP sensor was calibrated with too-close tolerances. If the engine hic-upped (backfired) it would shut down. There was no repair except to replace the MAP sensor. The bigger problem was replacement stock was the exact same part, and it took GM a while before an updated unit could be supplied. Dealers would disconnect the 8/6/4 feature, running it as an 8cyl only. The press had a field day. I inspected a limo in West Palm Beach, Florida, that the owner wanted all the interior chrome replaced. Someone had discharged a tear gas device inside the car that caused the damage ( the interior chrome pieces came from different suppliers, so it was impossible for all of it to be defective) and I denied the claim. It turned out the limo was owned by the owner of the newspaper 'The National Inquirer" (famous for stories like 'I got pregnant by an alien, etc.) They went on a HUGE hate campaign, smearing the vehicle, which only threw fuel on the fire. Those were tough times to be a Cadillac District Service manager.
Hydro locked, fuel drippage.
Did they put filter on with a 3/4 impact.

A fellar bought one of these off my buddy when I was in highschool for $150. It had no brakes, was throwing engine belts and the motor ran like trash but it had like grandma only went for groceries in it mileage. Found out the A/C pump was seized so we bypassed that with a 350gm engine belt and it ran but awfully cause of the 4-6-8 setup. There were sensors on the valve covers if you unplugged it would run on all 8 cylinders which fixed the motor not running right. I didn‚Äôt have a license so my cousin came to pick it up and drive it home (5min drive) but someone stole my temp tag and the police in my town were super corrupt they pulled us over and said they‚Äôd have to impound it for No tag. I told em they 100% were linked with the bmv and could see a valid tag was issued for it which was obviously stolen off it (we think by the original owner now angry I hit her running). Cops took her (and it was an insane amount to get her out so I left her) they harassed me at school for months to surrender the title which I kept passing around between friends and family cause they can‚Äôt get an abandonment title if it keeps changing hands within 30days. My grandfathers lawyer served the police for harassment and they finally left me alone. They had to scrap the car instead of auction it, we sent a friend to the scrapyard to try and buy it but they were apparently ordered not to sell the car üòÇ. I still hate police 30yrs later.

Derek, you are really on to something BIG I'd love to see you talk more about.  America's greatest years were when we had a race to the moon, Detroit was cranking out  well designed, well built high technology vehicles that a feller could learn about and own and FIX!  As the owner of a '65 Plymouth Fury III,  every time I get behind her wheel, I am always struck by how much car tech has evolved over the 60 years since she was built!  I understand why it was perfectly logical to computerize everything- to maximize fuel efficiency, to make the ride nicer, to make all the parts do smarter things, but... its all at the detriment of making auto tech out of the reach of the average feller! (Unfortunately that seems to be on purpose, which is a whole nother rabbit hole to explore! They don't want fellers fixing their cars!) Yep, the newer cars are minor miracles, and I have some of them too, and appreciate what they're good for!  But I can't maintain them like I can my '65!  And I can't understand the more and more cryptic logic behind how their dern computers are thinkin'!    You have an amazing channel, obviously you've struck a nerve with fellers that like being able to Bring On The Thunder and keep the old tech around - if nothing else than to keep us conscious of what we've lost with all our high tech wizardry!  Your approach to every problem is a tribute to American Ingenuity, and can teach a feller how to think straight - about cars, about life, about family... and about the future and what it ought to look like!   I mostly keep vintage electronics alive, (scanimate.com) but I started out cleaning the carb on a VW beetle in 1968 and my Dad taught me how to use tools and break, fix, and make things!. I live near Asheville, NC and am from Kingsport TN. I'd be happy to give you a tour of my shop if you're ever over this way! Keep up the good work!

I am one of the suckers who bought an 81 Sedan Deville with that engineering abomination 8-6-4.  Biggest piece of sh!+ ever produced, and i regretted buying it from the first week, when it lost power.  Shop, fix, home, same problem.  Rinse and repeat..  No lemon laws back then, so I was suck with it until I traded for a Mark VI.  The 8-6-4 had god-awful drive-you-to-drink engineering.  Even running perfectly, it was rough running on 6 cylinders, and there were always reported performance issues--it was rolling garbage.   The 4 cylinder mode was so weak it wouldn't keep the car at speed above 45 miles an hour, except down hills.   Pretty car, just hideous engineering.  The 8-6-4 IS the reason I switched to Lincoln.  After a few months of it spending more time at the dealership than my garage, I picked it up from the Cadillac dealer running well and drove straight to the Lincoln dealer.  Bought an 82 Mark VI Givenchy. The Mark VI was quite a bit more expensive, but  It was one of the best cars I ever owned.  I drove it trouble free for 10 years.  It was a dramatically better built and better engineered car than the cadi-lackluster.  I've owned 8 Lincolns over the years (2 Marks, a Towncar, a Zehyr, an LS and a 3.0 TT MKZ, and 2 Navigators).  Even the Lincoln LS with coils that wouldn't last more than about 60K miles was dramatically better than that crap-box Caddy 8-6-4.

Those hubcaps looked like Oldsmobile hubcaps. I could be wrong but they look similar.  I had a 1981 Cadillac Sedan Deville. Bought it my junior year of high school in 2001 for 2500. It was Canari yellow. Mine had a leather interior though. Even had my senior pictures taken with it. It only had 104k on it when i bought it and was in near mint condition. Mine luckily had the 4-6-8 already overode...overridden....anywhos it only ran on 8 cylinders,  didn't kick down. My MPG sentinel  worked great though and did say 8 for the "active cylinders" button, when pressed. I do remember having problems with the electronic heater system and had fan motors go out a couple times for some reason. I did replace the plastics in the rear of mine also becasue i backed into my sisters boyfriends car and bow the one and it eventually broke out. My engine did always run great though. Never had an issue with it running. Did replace fuel pump  once and put air shocks on the rear end of it. i put the fill valve behind the license plate bracket in the rear. worked really well. Really loved that car about as much as my 1978 Lincoln Town Car i had when i was 16.  Unfortunately i let my dad take it to a Dr. appointment one morning and it was really foggy and he ran a stop sign at the end of a road and went off into a 4 foot drop into a ditch. The whole front end front the center front tires was bent upward at about at 30 to 40 degree angle. My dad was ok. Banged up a bit but he was so upset about it. I just told him i didnt give a crap about the car. I was so glad he was ok. and i told her (the car) before i got rid of it Thanks for protecting my dad,  Was a great car. next time you n'eed to keep an ecu alive gyy you have to discobnect cables. Use jumper cables to a second battery from the battery clamps‚Ä¶ old bmw trick, to reset the ecu. Disconect the neg battery post then touch it (the neg. Cable) to the positice post . Hold fir about 20 seconds and then put it back on the neg post. That will completely discharge all the electronics. And give you a totally fresh start. And no i am not trying to give you bad ibfo. Im 68 years old . Im way old school qnd hust never do that shit. My parents bought one of these 8-6-4 Cadillacs brand new in 1981.  I later heard about all of the problems, but theirs ran perfectly its whole life, and the 8-6-4 system worked perfectly.  It was a beautiful car in burgundy inside and out.  I was in high school learning to be a mechanic, so I bought all of the shop manuals.  I still have them.  The engine was a great idea, but like many have said, the electronics accompanying the system were not up to the task in many cases.  Sensors failing were the biggest problem most faced.  When I graduated and began working as a mechanic, owners would come in wanting the 8-6-4 disconnected because they heard they would cause problems.  Not that they had a problem, they just heard there were going to be problems, so I think the engine got a worse reputation than it deserved.

I worked at a Ford main dealer near London when the Cortina 80 was introduced fitted with the new VV carburettor. Ford boasted that its development cost ¬£60 million which wasn't much even then. Cold starting with the Motorcraft carb had always been marginal but the VV ensured our vast car park was filled to overflowing in winter;  cars sat for weeks awaiting attention. Ford introduced the 'VV programme' which was basically a matter of carb renewal and, initially, paid the cost, even when out of warranty. That soon changed and customers were then charged; it wasn't cheap. The irony was that cars fitted with the Weber carb had zero problems, but of course, Ford wanted to keep it all in house.

I think you messed up the TBI injectors when you removed the Allen screw in the top center of the injectors.  That screw is adjusted in the injector factory to set the flow rate and should not need to be adjusted.  New TBI injectors would be my choice as well as a new IACV.  Love your channel.   Very entertaining.

As a cancer survivor, I've learned to cherish every moment. In fact, I was told I had only 18 months to live with stage 4 cancer, and I gave away all my possessions, including my beloved 1976 Cadillac Coupe DeVille (white with red interior - it was oh so sweet!). But God had other plans, and here I am, 18 months later, still alive and kicking!  I've always been known for owning Cadillacs, and it's the only type of car I've ever owned. I could't find a technical explanation for how exactly this cylinder deactivation system [mechanically] works other than that the valves won't open or close in deactivated mode. The problem for me to understand was that there would be compression on every revolution in that mode, and resistance would act as an engine brake. There must be a mechanism of sorts that keeps the valves partly open was my reasoning.  But NO. I finally, after an immense search, found an explanation for this.  "It may seem inefficient to close the valves in a non-operating cylinder, forcing the piston to compress the exhaust gas trapped within. However, that ‚Äòwork‚Äô stroke is balanced by the successive ‚Äòexpansion‚Äô stroke as the piston falls, so the net result is very little power consumption."    OK . . .   if they say so
Hindsight is 43/100- probably would have been easier to have o‚Äôrileys throw in a naturally aspirated crate 350 and just engine swapped it

Its definitely the coolant temp sensor, i have a late 80s k2500 with the 305 TBI and had the exact issue. The ECM relys on MAP, and coolant temp on start and warm up, which determines idle, timing and injector pulses. If you unplug it, it wont run right, but should run better, with less fuel being dumped in it.
I know the TBi in the trucks would do the same thing if the coolant temp sensor was bad. The dash would read but the computer would think it‚Äôs -56 outside and dump fuel.
Those are Oldsmobile hubcaps.

My 92 caddy had the same issue where after resetting ecm it would start right up but the second attempt things would go haywire. I put in a new ecm and bingo many things were fixed. Clogged fuel injectors from a vehicle sitting long periods of time will destroy the fuel injection transistors in an ecm. My caddy would start up at 4000 rpm eventually when the computer bit the bullet. Installed new ecm fixed it

Derrick I remember when those 8 6 4 Caddys came out, they were the worst Caddys ever made along with the 76 Seville deseasal .. the 79 was probably the best car of that era with the 425 CI, I had 2 of them.. they had real Cadillac engines I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve worked on them.. but the best way to save the car is convert it to a 425 with electronic ignition simple and reliable. Yeah Cadillac really shot themselves in the foot with the 81‚Äôs then they came out with the HT 4100 that were slightly better till the head gaskets blew.. I believe in 86 or 87 they started putting Oldsmobile 307‚Äôs in them which were great engines but people that bought them got pissed when they found out they bought a Caddy with an olds engine for a Cadillac price tag, I believe there were lawsuits..but they kept the 307‚Äôs for quite a while till the 281 Northstar motors came out( AKA the death star) because those blew out head gaskets as I‚Äôm sure you know, the problem was the head bolts not the heads or the gaskets.. they redesigned the bolts in 2004 and those were good engines except 90% developed major motor oil leaks at around 100K miles and the motors had to be taken out and resealed to fix them because they were split blocks.. all in all Cadillac engine designs were bad from 81 till now‚Ä¶even the 3.6‚Äôs they put in most most CTS‚Äôs and XTS‚Äôs developed correlation codes for stretched timing chains..now the motors are 4 bangers with turbo chargers.. your level of patience is alarming
Been enjoying your video presentations. As for this Cadillac you're working on... When you found the gas tank sitting inside the trunk, my first thought (idea) of why this was, is because in some states, the removal of the tank made it be considered no longer an "automobile" per state automotive insurance regulations. By removing the gas tank, the State wouldn't require insurance to be maintained on the vehicle. Even if the car was a "parts car", the State could fine the owner for not having current insurance on it; so by removing the tank, it circumnavigated the "must be insured" requirement. I suspect that that is why the tank was removed by the owner.  Now, as for that 4-6-8 .... I owned a multitude of early to mid 1980s Cadillac limousines. I was 18 years old in 1984, and a business associate of mine owned one of these 468 caddies. It was a total disaster. I remember me going for a ride with him in his 468 to meet up with an associate of his, who lived in Northeastern Ohio, who was an electrical engineer for GM.  This guy was the one who actually designed the computer chip for GM. I remember he and my friend discussing this chip. The guy said that he told GM that the computer chip would never work properly, but they insisted he make it work. In short, my friend said this guy had designed a "new" (non-sanctioned) chip that could replace the GM chip, which would override the factory chip, and would make the car ALWAYS run as an 8 cyl.  Well, anyway... yeah, that 468 was notoriously a complete failure. Was a great idea, but the technology to make it work just wasn't there yet.

Derek: I'm just gonna work on TBI cars from now on....  Pretty sweet....  Heh heh heh heh heh!!!!  You can't win 'em all....  You can't.  Those things were hard to fix when new....
The green connector next to the throttle body is used to set the TPS voltage to .5v at closed throttle.  When you replace the TPS you use a volt meter to set it.  If it is other then .5v at closed throttle the engine will run rough and stall.  Also, the stepper motor is non-adjustable.  I would replace it.  Once someone turns the threaded screw it is hard to get it back calibrated.  I worked as a tech at Cadillac back in these days.

I thought it most likely the phase converter on the thermocoupler affecting the left ear and the right ear meaning it is going to be difficult reading the final front ear, have you asked Spok what he thinks
Also=Remember+ Every A-C Delco replacement Sensor/Switch/Etc. has about an 85-90% of working correctly/being a good part===Every aftermarket part has about a 20% chance of being better than the part that you took off==Use ONLY A-C Delco sensor+parts===That aftermarket O2 sensor that you replaced could also cause a full rich condition on it's own????..Bill.
Without a scan tool of some kind (I used the Tech2 for MANY years), you are just spinning your wheels. You NEED to know what are the primary. codes that are set.?? You will get the valve sol. codes since they are disconnected -disregard those for now. My first, and not ever mentioned in the video would be coolant sensor, and MAP sensor readings. An open sensor output on either of these sensor streams will make the TBI go full rich..??? Again without access to scan data you are just "Spinning your Wheels" This info is worth what you paid for it, but comes from a retired (40+ years) GM Master Tech. Best to you...Bill.

If it has an oxygen sensor, the missing cat will cause air to cycle back in and make it think it is running really lean - then it will dump in a lot of fuel to even out the AFR.  That or your injectors have failed open, perhaps with some grit stuck in them.

Ah yes... you pulled out that injector solenoid, im sitting here thinking about riello oil burners... the valve stems like to get sticky, and they kinda jam about halfway open and the fuel pressure gets all wonky and it won't fire right. So pop off the coil, pull the valve stem and give 'er the old shake/thwap a few times, then she starts clicking when you shake it, jam 'er back in and away you go.   It probably won't burn the house down... it'll be fine. Nope. Riello fuel pumps are trash. It's gonna bugger up again, and even if you put a new one on, it'll probably be bad out of the box.  Thanks carrier for buying riello.

I maybe wrong but I think the reason it runs better with the injectors unplugged could be that the injectors might be fitted wrong. At 51.30 he fitted the injector seal into the TB as it appears it should be fitted. After not being able to assemble the TB after fitting the injectors at 52.15 he removes this seal from the TB and fits it direct to the injector, then hammers the injector in so he can fit the top again. If the injector seal doesnt seal, fuel pump pressure will cause fuel to leak past the injecter - so will run but not right. Then when the injector plug is connected its running super super rich, wont fire, and fills the motor with fuel

üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ  I can‚Äôt stop laughing
The 468 functionality on a 368 is enabled via 3rd gear. Snipping the wire to the trans for the 3rd gear sensor or putting a switch in between to enable and disable as you please is what we used to do. Disconnecting the solenoids accomplishes the same thing, as well. The 468 functionality has no effect on Check Engine light or emissions, for that matter, which is ironic. If it was our own vehicle, we'd simply swap the rocker trusses, throw on 472 valve covers and be done with it. Looked and ran much better. 368 was bullet proof after that besides TPS and MAP sensors going bad from time to time.
I have never watched a 2 hour YouTube video until this guy... I really enjoyed it and was hoping to see u drive it home...A for effort

The first thing the pcm looks at in any fuel injection system is the coolant temp sensor. The computer tells it how much fuel it needs going off engine temp at start. The last thing it looks at is the 02's. I'll bet anything it has a bad coolant temp sensor.

The 8-6-4 system was definitely not ready when Cadillac rolled it out. I used to work in a Cadillac's only wrecking yard, and if I remember right this engine is just a downsized version of the 472 engines in your 1969 and 1970 DeVille's. The same basic engine went from 472, up to 500, down to 425 and finally had it's last go as a 368. I think a swap with the engine from your 1969 would be cool and fairly easy :)

You know that wierd half-moon transport device/ thing you have to take off every new grinder before you can use it on YouTube?   Well, I made an amazing discovery a while back, if you put it back on and just ignore that fact it looks really close to the spinny/ cutty bit, it does a grand job of stopping those grinding sparks and dust going up your nose.  Also helps stop those annoying cauterised cuts down to the knuckle bone from holding the grinder too close to the spinny cutty bit.  Just a thought.

IN THE 70'S MY DAD OWNED A '75 FLEETWOOD WITH A 500, & A '77 COUPE WITH A 425. WHEN THIS FREEKING LEMON CAME OUT, OL POPS CALLED IT THE "TWO-FOUR-SIX-EIGHT, WOW DO WE DEPRECIATE" ENGINE.... ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£
1 ) . 1977-1979 425 is carb run , all brackets fit 368cu in caddy ( detuned cu inches in cylinders) use all the front assembly and may need the HEI TOO. Intake fits.  Now isolate {+} wire to coil . All censors can be cut off. All air pump removed, and all hoses to it.  ECM IS A SPLIT BRAIN , so trans does not recognize  the trans in running. Engine and trans are separate from each other. Pluck check engine lamp. Most do not know the ECM IS SPILT . Tranny can still have Over drive  shift. . No censors are needed , just leave exhausted censor as a plug. If has air pump tubes to exhaust manifold, plug with plumber plugs , steel.  Cadillac motor sports has headers and alum intake and cams. 425 heads may be bigger valves.  (425 is a detuned 472/500) motor was good, electronics all failed. Motor ran, need to rid electronics. If ECM bad , try 77-79,  should work. Ps hubcaps were Olds 98.  225/75/15 were tires not 215. Most upped to 235 better ride. Radios failed in electronic connects. Heaters and fan fail too due to corrosion contacts. Move back to MN.

The o2 sensor was a good shout but they take a lot longer than a few seconds to go into closed loop. It was more likely trying to shut off cylinders which requires the remaining cylinders to work harder

I remember she had 1 of these V8,6,4s. That and the bad NY winter of 80 really inconvenienced her 30mi county drive 2 her, then 25yr, Westinghouse job. The dealer provided her a comparable loaner during the ordeal. I think others may be correct about temp sensor, I have a 2004 honda crv, changed coolant, after a few minutes of driving it switched off, started straight away, then as soon as moving it switched off, apparently you get a small air bubble under the temp sensor, so it switches off as a fail safe because the computer is not getting a signal from temp sensor, few minutes of driving and the air moves and dissipates, no more problem,  stupid.

Hi Derek! These TBi engines are great when they're working correctly. I know they're a pain when they're not, you know this already, but you must be able to get a trouble code from the computer. If not, that's the first place to start. Once the computer can tell you the trouble code, it's a simple matter of replacing the defective sensor indicated. A computer for an '81 Caddy is going for about $150 at evil bay. It's worth a shot before adapting a 650 double pumper (maybe the double pumper would be cool though).

That generation ECM had issues with the boards cracking.  Diagnostics consisted of rapping on the passenger kick panel and if it died, you knew that was the problem.  It also sounds like a possible issue with the coolant temp sensor, that has ultimate authority on startup.  A bad one that thinks it's  -35 degrees will flood the engine... not as bad as a Honda from that time period, but it ain't good.  Good luck with it in the future if you decide to work on it further.

I sat down and thought about this video for several hours and I think I might know the solution.  When the computer is erased and battery re connected it idles fine and runs good, but then you shout ot off and next start the engine wont run right and it stalls.  I think the computer is triggering the 8 6 and 4 mechanism and setting it up to crank on maybe only 4 cylinders once the engine is warmed up.  So I would look for what controls the 8 6 and 4 and remove any relay or fuse or even some electronic box.  We know such an entity exist or how would it work while driving the car?  Or why not buy a used computer box that is off of a chevrolet V8 car that had the 350 engine with the same throttle body and two injectors. plus it wouldnt operate any external 8 6 4 BS at all but would be designed to run the two injectors
Great stuff.  PPE is your friend üòä

I am a man that has owned around 50 Cadillacs for my own use from the late 70s to present and currently have a 1989 white brougham 4 door cadillac with the much wanted 307 oldsmobile cast iron V8 with carburetor.  That V8 6 to 4 engine, heres what mechanics di to those for people.  The valve covers were removed and the electronics were removed from the valve covers and they were converted to being the standard V8 without the 8 6 and 4.  They are the 366 CI and are shockingly the lifetime same 500 CI cadillac cast iron block and heads.  After removiomg the 8 and 6 and 4 junk, that engine will last forever

1981 was pretty much the low point for the auto industry on just about every level, not the least of which was electronics.    My second brand new car was an '81 Caprice.  One of my friends was the service department foreman at a big Chevy dealer in another state.  I called and told him I was considering a new Caprice, and he highly recommended I avoid the standard V-6 (drivetrain too undersized for the B-body) and of course the notorious 350 diesel.  Both were causing problems and dissatisfied customers.  I took that advice and picked out a very nicely optioned model with a gas V-8.  It was a beautiful car, ran great, and I never had any problems with it in the two years I owned it except for... drum roll... the computer.  1981 was the first year for GM's Computer Command Control, aka the "3-C" system, and it was problematic right from the get-go.  On three or four occasions while driving normally the 3-C light would suddenly come on and the engine would bog down.  After a few seconds the light would go off and the engine would return to running normally.  Each time, back to the dealership for a warranty claim we went, and each time they replaced a PROM and it was fine again for a while.  They told me the computer was glitching and kicking the mixture over to rich, which was why it felt like it was bogging down.  They said they were seeing a lot of similar problems with the 3-C system in the new '81's.  It sounded like they were getting a little exasperated with it.    Online write-ups about the 3-C system confirm that the first couple of model years had issues, but apparently by '84 a lot of the problems were ironed out.  Typical GM especially of that era, using their customers as beta testers.  Other than the recurring computer issues I had zero problems with the Caprice, which was an unusually smooth new car experience for that era.  Many of the V-6 (weak transmissions), diesel 350, and V8-6-4 buyers of that era were not so lucky.

I have owned a couple of these. A simple intercept of the high gear signal wire from the driver side of the transmission will bypass the 8-6-4 system. There is also a single pole plug under the hood to bypass the digital computer for analog. Hold the "OFF" and "Warmer" buttons on the AC control for a few seconds to enter the built-in diagnostics. It will allow you to see all sensor values and even cycle all solenoids... enjoy!

2:03:08 you're welcome lol
Rotella oil no longer has a high zinc content.
41:14  An injector is a one way valve.  You can clean it by shooting carb cleaner in the cylinder head end.  Also whacking it on the fuel rail end can break it loose if it's stuck.  Think of it like a plunger plugging a hole.  Fuel pressure pushes on the back of the plunger to keep it closed.  When it gets power the plunger gets pulled out of the hole letting fuel out. Also, only use a 9V battery like Derek showed.  If you try to use full 12V battery voltage it's really easy to melt the coil.  They are only meant to be pulsed with power.  They aren't meant to be on all the time.

Dude, wear eye protection when cutting metal.  I did the same thing you did- close my eyes, but still managed to get metal in one.  Didn't even know it had happened till about a week later.  That's because the metal is hot, and it burns itself into your cornea.  You don't even feel it.  Then, as the days go by, it works its way to the surface.  Which, in my case once that happened, it felt like I had something stuck in my eye.  First eye doc removed the metal, but had to refer me to a different one to remove the rust.  Yes, rust.  Because it had been in there for a while.  That doc got the rust out, sent me home with some antibiotic drops, but I still ended up in the ER later that Friday night, with an ulcerated cornea.  (Deep abrasion, basically.)  The only thing that saved me was having Proparacaine drops.  The drops that, as soon as you put them in, makes it feel like whatever was in your eye is now suddenly gone.  And the ER doc didn't even want to send me home with them, after she was told by the on-call opthamologist at another hospital that they would delay healing, and I should not use them.  But she'd already given them to me prior to speaking with that other doc, and apparently forgot she'd done so, so they went with me!  I had to put ointment and those drops and antibiotic drops into my eye 5x's a day for the full week it took for my cornea to heal itself.  Which I learned, it does.  But in the meantime, your cornea gets scratched all to hell, and you're absolutely miserable, without those eye-numbing drops.  TL;DR   Don't do that.  I've gotten shit in my eyes 4x's in my life (twice wasn't my fault, and the other time I was only 16, grinding metal, and just didn't know any better) that sent me to the eye doc to get removed, so now, I won't even make a simple cut (I'm actually a carpenter) without first putting on eye protection.  And, love your projects!

I worked for GMAC  when the Cadillac  4/6/8 engine came out in 81. I was a credit rep in  Portland Oregon .We were constantly  setting up Product Complaints from Owners who shelled out $36,000 for a car that left them doing 20mph on the sholder of interstate 80 by Multnomah  falls for 3hrs trying to limp back to portland. People walked away from their loans. In droves. This was 2 yrs after Gm's famous  1979 diesel engine in pickups that had s 100% fail rate by 20,000 miles. And that was sfter the famous  Chevy Vegas with the warped blocks. Roger Smith was head of GM and platformed all the cars to make more money. He began the destruction  of GM. Eventually  Selling the one thing that kept the company afloat,  GMAC,the finance arm of GM. Later came bankruptcy  and droping Pontiac, oldsmobile,ect.üò¢
Sell your cats to ABCat tech for top dollar I just got $793 a piece for the cats off the 7 super duty I had come into this spring in TX they alhad 3 cats 1 on each manifold and 1 between the Y-pipe and the 4 or 5 foot Ford mufflers and with 3 empty 53 ft flatdecks it was worth loading them up with the rears together and strapping some crown vics on the 4 with flatbeds turned a pacer upside down in the longbed got a couple round back wagons a few prerun derby cars few Toyota cameras and cavaliers the 2 shortness got engines tranys fuel cells derby shifters and pedals when we went to the Minnesota throw down derby with my square body utility bed and 30 ft gooseneck with a round back wagon and 2 camerys all the cats I sold paid for the trip and the whole weekend my boys got to meet new people and run a new place and I sold the round back as a roller for just shy of what I paid for it as a driver the people up north couldn't believe the lack of rust several guys gave me a shopping list and their budget with a couple of my connections in TX and NV and the people they know with piles of cars in AZ and NM hopefully my winter is busy hauling cars to northern UT MN just outside Pittsburgh PA and upstate NY I have almost everything I've been asked for in my yard but Midwestern vehicles aren't as clean as desert vehicles and I can get them way cheaper than I can sell them for just to be welded up and crashed

No such thing as a carb swap. wishful thinking.   You are tackling the biggest cluster F#@k Gm ever came out with.  BTW.  you press= off and warmer = to get codes. Not off and higher.  There was no handheld scan tool for 81 Caddys, just the dash panel. And if they did make one It was one year only, and AC Delco charged you about $7-9,000 for it.   I suggest you have your generic book out telling you what buttons to push in what sequence to get codes for which system, engine trans, HVAC cruise etc.,   what value you have for, say TPS, MAP, rpm etc. and join and in.  The worst problem you will encounter is all the genius 6th grade dropout that have previously molested the poor caddy. Once you get all the molestation restored to factory specs, pull and correct the codes the car has make sure the mechanical stuff is in good order (don't worry about computer crap just yet, good fuel and pressure and good plugs and wires, and no vacuum leaks, THEN you might consider a bad ECM.  One good thing they don't need 'flashed' or a prom updated or any of that later model stuff (newer than 1988 or so. When you put yourself in the engineers' shoes with the EPA, national traffic safety folks, CAFE (corporate average fuel economy) consumers, upper management and on and on, it's a miracle they got the damn thing off the assembly line at all.  Seriously, if those guys could commit suicide 3 times a day, they would. They were given a task that was so close to impossible I bet there are not 5 of the original engineers alive today. Dealerships could not keep techs no matter what they paid them. They would not stay fixed more than a week or two in a row. And it wasn't just GM, Ford and Mopar had their fair share of cluster f38kstoo. Amazingly the japs fairs\ed quite well in the early days of on-board computers, Europe, not so well but still better than the big 3. I don't know but maybe Edelbrock makes an intake for this beast now. Then just gut your Distibutor and convert it to a standard HEI or buy a red cap Chinese one for $69.95, then put an Edelbrock carb on OR HAVE A MACHINIST make you an adapter to put a carb on your intake. Maybe Ebay has one now!  I started running away from those things in about 1985 and have not slowed down since. Never again for me. Maybe you will get to that point too. Good luck.

I had a friend who was like Derek with cars. His wife had a 80s model fleetwood they called the boat. Well one day the crank snapped in half and run on 4 cylinders. So his father being who he was went to a junkyard and got  500 out an old caddy.  To watch him work cutting out vacuum systems and other things saying don‚Äôt need that and that and that. Once he was done installing that beast of a motor fired right up. Never been in a caddy with so much power as you sink right in the seats when you floored it. They had that car for years and never gave them any trouble. His father said when you over complicate an engine is when you start having so many issues down the road. He sure was anti tech on cars.   So put a 500 swap in there and have fun with the caddy.

For me, this was the most stressful episode of Vice Grip Garage ever. The way you stuck with it was impressive though! Cantankerous Caddy‚Ä¶ the ole gal wasn‚Äôt having any of it. Heck‚Ä¶ even the brake drum had enough of her. I have a couple thoughts on those solenoids if you‚Äôre interested. If not, just ignore the following. You tested the solenoids with a 9V battery and you got them ‚Äúopening‚Äù and ‚Äúclosing‚Äù or ‚ÄúON‚Äù and ‚ÄúOFF‚Äùafter some cleaning and finagling of parts. More precise full ON and full OFF if that makes any sense, I dunno. Well, that could be fine if they operate always full ON or full OFF even if they‚Äôre a little ‚Äústicky‚Äù but I don‚Äôt think they do. If I were to guess, they‚Äôre controlled with PWM signals from the computer. I‚Äôm spitballing here. If you‚Äôre still reading‚Ä¶ WHY? üòú Well, you must be committed now. To continue, PWM will turn ON and OFF the solenoid to regulate the fuel delivery. With a possible ‚Äústinky‚Äù solenoid, I wonder if a PWM signal will OPEN and CLOSE the solenoid to operate as needed. It may be all ON or all OFF or somewhere in between. Hence, the dripping fuel after the key is OFF. Resetting the computer as you did several times, could and probably did pull the solenoid back to a position it needed to start running. Once the PWM signal starting fighting with the ‚Äústicky‚Äù solenoid‚Ä¶ oops,  two ‚Äústicky‚Äù solenoids, it flooded/locked. In the episode, you said it ran for longer periods of time. That kinda tells me the computer is doing its thing. So many sensors play roles in this, I may be way off with in my thinking. Although, I do have some experience with DC and AC solenoids. Can you test the signal to the solenoids? I‚Äôd have to refresh my memory on the internet. But‚Ä¶ I believe you can with some digital multimeters. Duty cycle, percent of voltage, or something along those lines‚Ä¶ maybe? ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Oscilloscope? Probably? Maybe? Like I said, I‚Äôm spitballing. An oscilloscope would probably give you a good visual of the signal to the solenoids. If you‚Äôre still reading‚Ä¶ WHY? üòú I apologize for such a long comment. I just wanted to throw out some ideas. I hope you revisit that dang Cantankerous Caddy in an episode soon. Did you soak the solenoid coils in cleaner? Did I see that in the episode? May not have been a good thing. I appreciate your support of veterans. Kind regards and respect, Doug.

I would check the coolant temp sensor, also the connection with the to corrosion on it after you plugged it in the car ran a lot better,that was probably the coolant temp sensor. The coolant temp sensor will default to minus 40 degrees and gives the car the fuel it needs for minus 40 degrees.

If it has a Coolant Temperature Sensor, unplug it. GM Throttle bodies are notorious for dumping fuel when the ECT sensor goes bad. Unplugging it will put it into a more neutral state and allow it to run. My 90 model showed -256 degrees on scanner and DUMPED fuel. Unplugged until I got a new one. HTH!

Ah yes the Mad Dog. I was a young tech at a Cadillac Dealership (my first job as a mechanic) there were so many problems with that engine, I could write a novel. If the electronic issues weren't enough, the plastic valve covers warped very quickly and leaked like a stuck pig, and the bug spray fuel injection loved to run super rich, caused by a sensor, that had no upgraded replacement. The fix for that was to solder a resistor into the harness at the throttle body.  These were also one of Cadillacs first attempts at a PCM, and it hated bumpy roads, saw a lot of those replaced as well.
That is one mess of an engine bay. Sorry this one didn‚Äôt work out as planned Derek. There‚Äôs always next time, cheers üçª
I had a 80s Chevy where i replaced basically all the sensors you could dream of. Wouldn‚Äôt ya know it still ran rich. What wound up being the issue was a Prom chip on the ECU. Not saying that‚Äôs it but maybe it could help.
One of the teaching demonstrations back in the early TBI days, both Ford and GM were pulling the coolant temp sensor wiring connector off the sensor made the TBI go full rich dumping fuel and stalling the engine, not sure what connector you pulled noted it was corroded then just plugged it back in and it ran.... but check it again, bad sensor (open circuit) will also cause it.

One easy, cheap and dirty way to test for some bad sensors without shotgun replacing them is to, one at a time, disconnect them and try to start and run.  Disconnecting a sensor will force the ECU to run open loop in Limp Mode.  This is a good way to diagnose a really whacky O2 or MAP sensor.  The only engine sensors that cannot be checked this way are Coolant Temp, Throttle Position and Crank Position sensors.

Forgot to mention the MAP sensor. Final recommendation and request: good MAP sensor, TPS, IAC, turn off the 4/6 modes per TSBs. I think you probably borked the drinker side injector. I've worked on many TBI units. I've seen this exact problem. The ECT "Engine Coolant Temperature" sensor and connector needs to be replaced. The ECM thinks the vehicle is at -40 degrees and will cause the injectors to go to a full rich condition. The vehicle will flood itself.

Wow Derek, this was a tough one, I could definitely feel your frustration.  I had a 84 Corvette that had that, "wonderful" Cross Fire Injection system. The first year I had it, it would do almost exactly what you are experiencing...it would dump fuel and computer wouldn't flash any codes. Out of desperation, I started tapping on sensors with a screwdriver.....I hit one and the thing started running great. It was the coolant temp switch. I replaced it and never had another bit of trouble out of it for the next 10 years. At the 10 year mark, it started having a intermittent fuel delivery problem where it would run great.....shut her off to go in a store, and then no Injection pulse on return. It eventually got to where I would be driving down the road and fuel delivery would just shut down. I tried everything to solve it but at the end I sold her and got a 85 Vette with the tune port injection and never looked back, lol.

Dad bought Mom a brand new Olds Delta 88 in 81 I think, that had the 350 diesel. Thing was a headache from the word go. Had constant problems with the fuel filter that we later found out was a water separation filter, it was an absolute PITA to get to, and the mechanical injection pump got replaced on about an anual basis under warranty. Once the warranty expired my dad took the pump to this guy who ran a heavy duty diesel truck shop whod been a froend for years, the guy took the pump completely apart and rebuilt the entire pump from top to bottom, made some modifications in the machine shop he had, replaced all the seals and several other things, basically blueprinted the entire thing. And dad added an extra water filter in a much easier to access location, added a block heater and a manual glowplug switch on the dash. After all that was done the car never really gave anymore troubke, just keep it pluggedb in if its very cold, and always long cycle the glowplugs. Best part is the reengineered injection pump never gave anymore trouble. Mom ended up putting a few hundred thousand on it, then sold it to a friend of hers who added a nother hundred k, snd sonething happened to the engine. Being as the lady we sild it to was a older single lady, when it does Dad helped her out, took it to a machanic friend, bought a mid 80s low milage chevy caprice or Buick something or other that was totaled and got the mechanic to swap in the 350 gasser and the car stayed on the road for many years after that. My sister also had an early 80s, I think 82 or 83 Monte Carlo that was also a diesel. Believe it ir not yes, there were diesel Monte Carlos. CRAZY. She got a lot of confused looks with that car, even had a few times where gas station people came runing out yelling at her  like shes crazy for putting diesel in it, one guy swore there was NO SUCH THING as a diesel MC. üòÇ

It was my car after that and was great until a rear-end collision bent the unibody and caused the rear capt. side door to leak in the rain.   We also discovered that the cigar lighter up front would randomly short/ blow the fuse and backfeed the dome light and kill the battery. An accidental drop of a penny into the lighter socket revealed this odd secret.   That and a jackleg replaced the water pump and left off a spacer that was essential to the belt alignment and was not shown in the parts catalog. It was also in that transition where there are both sae & metric fasteners under the hood.   Best of luck exorcising the spirits from that beast. If anyone can find a modern or retro reliability upgrade you can. Or you could drop it off at Wes Johnson‚Äôs place and we a Can Watch Wes Work on it.   He is probably one of the maybe 12 people that have the patience to solve that torture puzzle.
My experience with throttle body injection is that they're ok but it seems like the like to randomly stall the engine while going up a hill or long highway trips but only stall for a slight second and come back to life. It always made me nervous driving a TBI because of that but i noticed if i used a higher voltage ignition coil it usually made it run better? Doesn't make sense because the coil doesn't power the injectors they're powered by the ECM but every time i used a different coil other than a accel high voltage coil it would always do a weird stall thats why i just like the carburetors or actuall fuel injection because TBI is like one little break to being stranded on the side of the road.
There is an idle learn procedure that needs to be done whenever the battery is disconnected. I can‚Äôt remember exactly what it is though, that was years ago.  In order to properly diagnose that one you will need the climate control display to work properly and will likely need a service manual to tell you what to test for the codes stored. That is likely the only way you will get it running without throwing tons of money at it.

This is definitely one of my new all time favorites of VGG.  I have a 1980 Coupe Deville, and it runs great (just don‚Äôt expect much top end power!)  I always thought the V8-6-4 was an interesting idea and so far ahead of its time.  Unfortunately, like the Oldsmobile diesel, they were rushed to the market before they were ready, and I think this contributed to the loss of public opinion of GM long term.    I also like the longer show üòÖformat. Your camera operator has a great presence of mind to capture the brake drum carnage and not just get out of the way!  I really enjoyed that you went for something ‚Äúa little different‚Äù and not just the same old ‚Äúhere‚Äôs a new carb and now it runs good.‚Äù    Towards the end of the video it definitely seems like maybe you were suspecting computer issues, and rightfully so. The fact that the computer didn‚Äôt want to reset codes also seemed not right.  I had a similar experience with a 1995 Ford truck with the 300ci 6cyl; it would sometimes run just fine, but sometimes it would barely run.  I tried multiple times to get the computer to report codes and it wouldn‚Äôt cooperate.  What ended up fixing the problem for me was pulling the computer and replacing the electrolytic capacitors on the computer board. Like clutches, electrolytic caps will eventually fail‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just a matter of time.  People that repair old TV‚Äôs and radios often have to replace the leaky caps. When they fail they can leak all over the circuit board and ruin it as well.   The fact that cars see extreme temperatures usually speeds up the process of failure.  Check out @shango066 channel; he‚Äôs repaired a number of ECM‚Äôs over the years.  Cheap fix and worth a shot, before trying to track down a replacement computer.

This is one of those projects all of us car fellas have had,...and regretted cracking in to after breaking parts, wrestling with, laying under, and staring at for hours while asking "How is this fun?". Had a similar situation with an aftermarket Megasquirt FI system on a rally-built Volvo causing all 4 injectors to hang open, right down to the raw fuel in each cylinder.  Turned out to be bad capacitor or doohicky on the actual processor board. Nothing I could have done roadside would get it running.  Definitely makes you miss the simplicity of a carb.
You didn‚Äôt seat the lower injector o rings in the housing before putting the injectors in. Putting them on the injector first 100% will not work or seal. Raw fuel will bypass the pod straight down the throttle body. Everything else is the result of that. I knew it immediately when you seated the injectors. Orings in the housing lots of lube press injector‚Äôs straight down with consistent force to seat over injector. You would have had a runner. ECM and O2 only control trimming closed loop after warmup on these old systems. Open loop and start circuit is all on the ECM. Old TBIs are a dream.
Cadillac had originally developed an engine that would shut down cylinders on the road back in either the 30's or 40's and it was a failure as well.

Will have to say, GMs earliest TBI was a mess, in stark contrast to the near indestructible TBI that GM used until 1995 on, the GMT400. Also you do not know "What" had been messed with before you started wrenching. If you decide go with a computer check the wiring for shorts to ground, and damaged to any power leads. Hell you might find the computer is not getting a good power signal, or a poor ground.

We had a 1982 Cadillac Coupe Deville 4 door with the 4100 motor, it would struggle to drive up a steep grade. Then when it had about 75,000 miles it would stall after we drove it on the freeway for a while, then after a few minutes it would start again on the off ramp.  I noticed the wires to a sensor located near the carburetor were hot. It was some kind of fuel sensor.  I installed a new one and coated the mating surfaces with Permatex ultra and it solved the problem.

The deactivation system still worked, but the shifts to V6 and V4 were so jarring it felt like the engine was falling out. He unplugged the harness so it only ran in V8 mode. Derek check the fuse for the alternator particularly the wire that supplies 12 V to ignite the circuit for the alternator to charge I have seen in later Models on TBI injection That‚Äôs the fuse for the charging system also operates fuel management system and the vehicle will do what you‚Äôre experiencing where the overflowing and flooding is present not sure if this will help you and your situation but I have seen This exact thing happened when that fuse blows I did not get to catch in the video if you did get the vehicle charging but if that‚Äôs the case where are you did not check that first it may resolve the entire issue on how it will not idle

üê™üê™ Good Show! There's always a Camel! ... Bruce
Hey Derek! I really liked this episode of you working on a TBI styled Caddy. When I was a kid my Dad had some impressive rides, he had a Chevy Nova, a 442, A Cutlass Supreme and even a GTO.  He loved his GMs of the 70s. I learned so much with him on Carbs and rebuilding them, tuning them and such.... Until one day in my High School years, I saw someone pull up to my school in a 1970 Datsun 510 and I suddenly fell in love with Japanese Nostalgics.   When I was 18 I finally bought my own 510, as well as buying a few other old 70s Japanese and British cars 2 years later.  I had experience in working on the Hitachi and Weber Carbs and I found it fun doing triple side drafts on those 4 cylinder engines. My dad used to laugh at me being he loved the American Cars and working with Holleys and Edilbrocks. But he always encouraged me to keep exploring and learning. 25 years later, I still held onto my 510 and did a full TBI conversion last year replacing my Weber side drafts.   I will say I learned so much doing that swap and I find the motor being more responsive and etc.  My Dad was so impressed that he was driving the 510 for a solid week. Seeing you  working on a TBI was great to see as I was learning alot from the 80s style GM perspective. I liked how patient you are and very eager to know what is the center cause of the issue.   Much love man!

One more thing- the inlet and outlet on the back are removable so you just use 2 wrenches. One to hold the nipples and one to twist the fuel lines off of them. The nipples have a hard flat ring seal on each to seal them to the body of the R220 there at the back‚Ä¶
You disconnected the coolant temp sensor and plugged it back in that made it run good . They are known for that cts sensor going open then it dumps fuel .. it is the one at front of manifold yellow and black wire

Man those TBIs are a pain to get running after they‚Äôve sat for so long and when you do it will run good one min and not run at all the next, it‚Äôs so frustrating
Rochester 220 is really pretty simple. The trick on the injectors going in is this- the metal rings keep the injector body o-rings from rolling down on you and the tiny peg on the side of the injector indexes with the notches in the injector cavity for proper orientation. And you guessed the lube is needed to help it seat in the o-ring without ripping or twisting. It really is easier to pull the whole unit and do it on the bench. To pull the injectors you just pry under the tips once you get the top retainer plate off to get them off the seat and then pliers to gently pull them up and out.
You should have just LS swapped it and you you would have been fine üòÖ

My sister inherited an 81 Cadillac 8-6-4 Coupe DeVille from my dad in the late 90's. Well, she was never good with vehicles. For example, she had a 78 Malibu that she beat to heck, never any maintenance. She had to drive it 45 miles to take a test to be certified to be a respiratory therapist. She got off the interstate, and when she got to the light, the car was on fire. She left it and let it burn as she high tailed it to her appointment. Anyway the Cadillac's water pump went bad and a friend of her son's said he could fix it. He got it tore apart, removed the water pump, but never returned  to finish the job. It sat about 3 or 4 months. Then one day my dad says lets go fix your sisters car. All the brackets were disassembled there we're brackets off of other brackets, and we had no clue where everything went. We went to a parts store got the water pump and new belts and antifreeze, then the fun began. It took us about 4 hours of this looks like it goes there, but it didn't. Or maybe it goes there with this other bracket. By some miracle we got it back together. I remember when they got the car brand new it came with leather seats and a factory integrated C-B radio off the am fm radio cassette player. Another thing that never caught on.

1:51:10 Idle air control... you were headed in the right direction. That's why when adjusting the threads seemed to help. The little motor inside the iac is not working correctly. They have plastic gears inside of them that go bad. That's why revving at high idle sort of bypasses the IAC. That particular IAC motor is also used on the early Northstars and Dodge Dakotas, etc. IAC motor is what was making the clicky clacky sounds when the engine wasn't running at 1:41:50.  Replace IAC motor. It sounds too easy, but they just go bad.
God bless you for having the patience of Jobe, Good work though. Keep up the good work!

Oxygen sensor won‚Äôt fix your cold start, vehicle is in open loop (preset table based on temperature), so this won‚Äôt help you. Coolant sensor reading too cold will cause excessive fuel, bad MAP sensor (common on this style). Hi Derek sorry for bothering you but when will the duster be given away
I'm from Scotland but lived and worked in the States from 1988 until 1998. In 1989 I bought an immaculate 1981 Cadillac Coupe de Ville 8-6-4  from a retired American Airlines Captain for $3,500 when I was living in Chicago. It was Royal Blue with Navy Blue leather, solid steel hub caps with red inserts and the Cadillac emblem. I can't remember how many miles I put on it but I drove that car every where for two years.  Chicago to Miami and back (circa 3,000 miles), every weekend from Chicago to Milwaukee and back as my then girlfriend attended Marquette and it never missed a beat. If I remember correctly it cost roughly $20 to fill her up, around $1 a gallon then. The MPG Sentinel worked flawlessly and I remember it reading 16 mpg around town driving and high 20s on the motorway (highway) when the variable displacement system kicked in also showing how many cylinders were running. It was a 368 cubic inches (6 litres) L62 engine. Essentially a 6 litre V8 would become a 4.5 litre V6 or a 3 litre V4 when cruising. The one thing I did regularly was an oil and filter change and wash it. The only thing that went wrong in that time was the thermostat, driver's side window regulator and exhaust (muffler). When I eventually sold it the buyer contacted me about a month later saying it was falling apart and failing. Kinda like the Bluesmobile in the Blues Brothers movie when their mission was accomplished. üòÄ I still have photos of it but can't upload onto YouTube. I enjoyed this video as I haven't seen one since and the memories came flooding back. I guess it just proves, as with all vehicles they're meant to be driven because if they sit idle for prolonged periods it gives the mechanical gremlins a chance to set up shop and go to work. üëçüèª

The story goes that the college sold the idea to GM and they took it and proceeded to wreck it.  Great effort!!!

The main reason I actually DO like the TBI is that, for fuel injection, instead of having to replace 4, 6 or 8, depending on your motor, you only have to replace the two injectors. Now having said that, I had a 1989 Chevy Cheyenne with the 4.3 with TBI and it was a standard. The injectors were meh and needed a good cleaning but I had just gotten it. It went dead trying to go on a very steep hill because it wasnt getting enough gas. I do know how to drive standard. There was a car behind me and this truck still had the neutral safety switch. Thank God my dad was in the truck with me. I had my feet on the clutch and gas and he put his on the brake. I got her goin and got the rippems up enough and we were finally able to go. It was funny at the time. Im glad we got to share that experience. We were laughing the whole way back to the house.

carb swap an sell
It‚Äôs a gorgeous
Those injectors have those new o rings seated correctly? Maybe they are letting too much fuel past? Didn't seem like the parts store was 100% on the right rebuild kit the way Derek showed it near the beginning. Fuel injectors on my 1988 Crown Vic were leaking a bit. The car had a rough idle but not like with this Caddy. You can tell if they are not shutting off like they should by looking at them with the fuel pressure on full and not turning the engine over. They should be in 100% shut off, no fuel!  If they are off then maybe replacing the TPI was the answer, not sure if Derek actually got around to doing that.     IMPORTANT POINT: don't use a cheap meter to diagnose. They use too much power from their penlight battery and can damage sensitive computer sensors. Must use a high quality digital meter and or a LED test light. LED's use small power too. Doesn't have to be a $400 Fluke. I use an Ideal meter and even those low priced Chinese meters are great. I have two made by Vicimeter. One even lights up the display. VC97A is a wonderful meter for less than $40 on sale.    I should point out TPI sensors are just a variable resistor and can be checked with an ohm meter. Specs need to be known for what is correct though. A Haynes manual for fuel injection might provide that but for that one off maybe. TPI's are pretty much the same. Other GM vehicles that used advanced carburetors and O2 sensors probably would have the same specs. I replaced the injectors on the Crown Vic with used ones that did work correctly and the old Ford idles nice now. I have a little trick to test used fuel injectors off vehicle to see if they shut off 100%. If nobody wants to know that I'll just sit on that info.    I guess those old Caddy's did not have OBD1 ports or did Derek not really care why the engine light was on? Newer cars always dump more fuel in "limp home mode" so that might play a part here. That MPG Sentinel was shown as the computer sensor tester if the buttons are pushed in the right sequence. Another channel claimed there were no indicators generally to even see if you are doing anything with the Sentinel. Looks like fun project if you have the time to spend on it. Seemed the A/C compressor engaged while turning the engine over. Why?
Watching the EFI rebuild be done with a hammer was everything I pictured when I saw the title of this video... and to everyone who says working on cars must be so relaxing and peaceful, needs to watch the exhaust portion of this video. 100% relatable

I spent about an hour yelling at the screen to check/test/replace the coolant temp sensor.  Those early EFI systems had non-existent diagnostics, so you had to measure the "goesintos" and the "comesoutas" the ECM to see what it was seeing.  If the coolant temp sensor is unplugged, it thinks you are doing a cold start on the North pole, hence the flood of fuel.  If this wreck is still around, have someone check that and see what happens, I'd love to see it heading down the road somewhere.
I wish you could just somehow turn it into a v8 only just remove all electro-digitals.

You‚Äôll probably never see this but it‚Äôs the engine temperature sensor. It constantly thinks it‚Äôs cold so it keeps priming. Happened to my 87 Chevy

Easy fix... loose the ecm. Put a Holley 500 with TBI to 2bbl carb adapter. Toss the computer controlled distributor. Put a distributor from a Cad 500 in there. Put a simple toggle switch to activate & deactivate from 4 cylinders to V8 at your will. I've done this several times

I had a fuel dumping problem with my Toilet Bowl Injection and it ended up being the engine temperature sensor and its connection.
I've owned two of those, my first one being an identical copy of what you're working on, and my second one a Fleetwood Brougham coupe.  That engine was very misunderstood by the media, as there was nothing really wrong with it.  Granted, the computer was not fast enough, and cause drivability problems/lunging because the computer was too slow, and would wait too long to re-add cylinders.  To successfully use the car one only needed to cut the sense line from the tranmission to the computer so it always stayed in V8 mode.  It didn't save a drop of gasoline, but was still a cast iron Cadillac motor, with that fantastic TH400 bull-stout transmission. I drove the first one past 200,000 miles, and the second one past 150,000, paying a total of $2,200 for both cars - one heck of a good buy.  That Fleetwood Brougham coupe is still floating around in my neighborhood somewhere.  The car was under-powered, but still smooth as glass and genuine Cadillac rugged.  It was the last gasps of air for cast iron blocks, as the next year HT4100 was a total disaster for Cadillac and anyone who bought one.  I do like your comical descriptions of certain parts, such as "shift juice."  Reminds me of blinker fluid.

is it possible, and i don't know if you had already checked it, but i know with most 1 gen fuel injection, no matter the manufacturer, that if the coolant temp sensor has failed, i've seen obd 1 ford fuel injection have hard starting, over fueling issues, lean fueling, rough idle, etc until warm .  then completely run fine, as it turned out the coolant temp sensor was telling the computer that the engine was warm, giving a "warm engine" fuel map (to lean for a cold engine), and until the engine physically was warmed up, it would run like crap.  When i seen this one giving full tilt on fuel, it made me think that possibly the ect sensor is telling the computer the engine is cold and to give more fuel.  just a thought.

Whoa, this was painful to watch! I worked in an independent garage in the late 80s and we had quite a few 4,6,8s. This was an incredibly frustrating era of cars to be cutting my teeth on as you now know! Anyway, all of them had the solenoids disconnected. My shot from the hip is that it's the coolant temp sensor. Also, those screws on the injectors adjust the amount of fuel they deliver. If memory serves they were set at manufacture and not intended to be adjusted in the field. Also - hold off then add warmer. The two dots mean you're in diagnostic mode. I believe it will stay in open loop (no O2 sensor input) as long as that's going. I don't remember how but there's a way to cycle through the sensor readings that the computer is seeing. Pretty sure you'd see one of those was -40 and that would be the bad coolant temp sensor. Fwiw - I don't think the ECM is bad. I don't know how youd ever even find this comment! Hope it helps if you do.

If the ECM is bad, crack it open. I'll bet you'll find every electrolytic capacitor leaking out their electrolyte onto the circuit board. This is what happened to my 1992 F-150. I replaced the capacitors. Put the ECM back into my truck and it ran fine. Electrolytic capacitors have a finite lifetime.

I don‚Äôt think GM TBI fuel injection from the 80‚Äôs worked like a modern ECU. It was a while ago, but I think they start in open loop mode with a fixed map on temperature, manifold pressure, and throttle position. Once it warms up, it switches to closed loop mode where it mostly uses the O2 sensor. I bet when it was running good it was because it was in closed loop mode. Getting it to run long enough to switch to closed loop looked difficult though.

I think that cat had things to do with your problem. It holds back pressure for the exhaust valves. It changes how the cams interact which the valves. changing the cam shaft position sensor. Now it‚Äôs telling the ecm that you‚Äôre half throttle when it‚Äôs at idle. Everyone thinks that style cat is full when it‚Äôs not. For the v4/6/8. It has different throats for the correct back pressure as the ecm deadening cams,lifters, and spark to change it from v8 to v6 then down to v4. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Just a thought. I don‚Äôt know if you verified the bad ecu or not but I had a similar problem with an older ecu car with the same type of dual point injection system.  Never could figure it out until I came across a random forum.  Same symptoms, replaced the water temperature system and that fixed it.  Bad temp sensor tells the ecu it‚Äôs below freezing and to dump all the fuel it can for some reason.  Worth a try

I‚Äôve owned 10+ gm tbi vehicles and have fixed many issues over the years. At the time it was frustrating but now that I‚Äôve been through all the issues I have I personally love gm tbi, please don‚Äôt give up on it, you got this.
As my older brother worked for GM from 1978 to 1988 I heard a few stories of lets say poor attempts of early electronic application of, at the time ‚ÄòCCC‚Äù  Computer Command Control. You were on the right track cleaning out the TBI injector and the car actually running. Had you just cut the heater hoses and bypassed the it you might have been able to drive it home. You see it was a common problem, the leaking heater cores, well they leaked right on to the computers. And that was that. There lots of other issues the GM designed in problems. The adaption of a carburetor and ignition has been done a few times and with good success.  As far as the 4/6/8 as you unplugged the solenoid that's was all you needed to bypass it .

the reason that motor was for 1 year only was cause they introduced HT4100 from 1982 to 1985 in 1986 Cadillac finally put the Oldsmobile 307 in the Fleetwood's only up until 89 then they put the chevy 350 in them up from 1990 to 1996.  to check the computer system hold the off button and the warm button at the same time  the 4 codes that will come up will be 21 22 24 27 that is the ECM under the distributor cap  when you change it you have to change the other module on the steering column the 2 control the 4-6-8

No way you can read all of these comments, so I feel free to add my $0.02.  I know that the TBI is not the greatest of FI systems (better than a SPICA and old Bosch for sure), but I've had to rebuild a few of them and my Chevrolets run pretty well after doing them.  Getting the O-rings set properly is one of the keys, otherwise you get fuel running everywhere, and too much of it.  That said, your intestinal fortitude in fighting that POS has my utmost admiration.  I'd have had to walk away 50 times cursing, have a beer or a bourbon shot, sleep, and come back to it refreshed, only to be defeated again.  This engine and their diesel attempts were as badly engineered as anything Detroit has ever produced...and that's saying something.  If you didn't know it already, you're not alone.  I've been wrenching since my late teens (in my 70s now) on all sorts of metal.  There's nothing quite like the defeat that an inanimate object like a car can do to one's self-respect to say nothing about one's maturity of response.  At least I've stopped throwing things, learned to breathe deeply, and walk away leaving it for another day.

Back in the early 90's, I suffered through the same issues on my 1981 Coupe Deville.  I spent more time chasing electrical issues and changing computers than actually driving the car.  There was a workaround to disable the 8-4-6 function that helped with reliability that the prior owner had done before my acquisition. When it did run, it was a couch on wheels and a pleasure to drive.  I had a love-hate relationship with that car.   I eventually gave it to my brother who spent the next few years chasing the same problems until he also gave up and got rid of it.
That one put up a fight.  I honestly think it's the computer too.  Also, the off and warmer does code stuff but I moreso think it's on 1989-1993 or so Cadillacs. I would enable off and warmer to view codes on fuel display and the end of the run (or no codes) was 7.0... then off and hi buttons would clear any codes, and press auto to go back to climate control.    I have a service manual for 1992 that goes super in depth on how to disable individual injectors, view O2 readout, turn on or off EGR, actuate idle speed control motor, etc.    I do think that's all your Caddy needs at this point is the computer though as it sounds like it's shutting down after a few seconds.   I wonder if the sensors are losing their 5V reference when the computer goes nuts.    At any rate, I like the idea of disabling the V6/V4 stuff, and or even just going carbureted.  I also like the idea of an LS swap or something.  She's too nice to end up in a junkyard.

Take it to the junkyard. I run into stuff like this with HVAC units that were made in the inbetween years. The circuit board stuff isn't fully integrated yet and you get this half solid state half analog stuff that if it's not working and its a huge pain to fix. That Caddy imo is one of those things that if you can do your normal deal to it and it comes alive and drives that's great. Do something with it. But if theres all kinds of gremlins just cut your losses. If someone likes that car they could pull all that old stuff and put one of the new fuel systems on it. How much do you like it? Also, those years with the gaps where the plastic is gone look horrible. I mean I know we're all about patina but those chunks missing is another deal. I see one running around every now and again and they look a bit more than ghetto.
In the video I did not see you check. the fuel pressure.  Recently My friend and I worked on his 350 with the Holly sniper fuel injection after 2 shops could not figure out the issue.  I will say at this point I am not an fuel injection expert by and stretch of the imagination.  My expertise is with Jet engines and motorcycle's.  What we found with some trouble shooting was the return line to the tank had been pinched on installation and was causing the fuel pressure to be at 100PSI.  The problems this was causing was very similar to the issues you were experiencing.I'm not saying this is your issue but I would  put a pressure gauge on both pressure and return sides and make sure your delivery  is correct before I did anything else. Not sure what the fuel pressure is supposed to be on the Caddy but on the Holley sniper it is 58 to 61PSI
Man i hate this. I think if you have time you should come back to these car and give it another shot.

I would have started with a "To don't list"
Probably not a good suggestion, but your lack of familiarity with TBI engines and the fact that if is an 8-6-4, leads me to believe you are overlooking some basic troubleshooting issues. If there is someone who is familiar with old GM TBI engines you could contact, or someone on this channel who is real familiar with TBI, I think this could be made to run good. I DID work on these years ago at the dealership, primarily disabling the selective cylinder feature. The usually ran good AFTER this was done , except for fuel mileage. NO, it was a bad idea, but GM was trying to meet CAFE standards as set forth by the EPA, just like today. The EPA needs to be abolished. It is way too powerful Even today, many years later and better technology,  GM's variable displacement engine in the trucks , turned out to be a huge problem. Also, I don't believe you were preforming the onboard diagnostics correctly. These computers would clear soft codes when the ignition switch was turned off. Hard failures , like what you had would stay in the computer until resolved. Find an OBD1 scan tool that might help (good luck finding one)

EFI FAILURE - happened to me and a friend on the way skiing between Athen,GA & Boone,NC,  In a 1982ish Citation (single TBI).  ECU commanded full flood. To preserve our record of never being stranded by a car, I splice the radar detector wire into the TBD solenoid connection.  While me friend drove, I 'pulsed' the wired to get us moving, then held them for full throttle (all 70hp) until we could coast into a shop just before dawn.  Another friend picked up a new ECU from the dealer next to our parents town and he delivered it to us after borrowing a car to ski and make it to a hotel.  Plugged in the new ECU and drove it home.

Our family owned 3 vehicles with the 5.7 diesel engine, two had some success, but the other, and  ironically the newest got 2 new engines, on GMs tab (we still have it).   The last GM diesel we bought was the 4.3 diesel (v6) had well over 300k on it when  i sold it to a guy that put another 100k on it. I am definitely interested in a carb swap.
In an age when owning a Caddy was viewed as a sign of success my father bought the Seville sedan version with the same engine. Besides the electronics being an engineering nightmare to diagnose for technicians there was a real world drivability issue. If the sensors didnt read full throttle acceleration the engine would try to cut back on active cylinders while the transmission was trying to upshift and it caused a hesitation much like the feeling you get from a modern engine with a bad coil pack. Annoying to say the least.
This reminds me of troubleshooting my 85 project corvette.  Couldn't tell you how many times I had to jump the obd plug to count those stupid service engine light flashes but I figure it out...eventually.  I had a really similar issue as yours on an older TBI s10...ended up being the temp sensor causing the problem (*&^*(&$%^*&^%&*^%
I had a 91 firebird expirencing similar issues. I came to the conclusion that the wiring casing, the terminals, and the connectors being 30+ years old can not transmit and receive a consistent signal. When you have a system that is run off of analog values, it's very important that they are consistent. I would go as far as to say, unless it's been 100% rewired and you have brand new sensors, you're going to have issues. Carb swap it, hillborn scoop out of the hood, and swap a dually axel in it. Lol, make it a freak of nature.

Honestly, I‚Äôd rather have one of the V-8-6-4 engines than the HT4100 which followed.  If you disable the electronics, the 8-6-4 is just a tough, old, all-iron, smaller displacement version of the 472/500 engine family, and will run as a v8 with a carburetor and HEI just fine.  Forever.  The 4100 came off the assembly line as scrap metal. Derek, I'm guessing the flooding issue is when you originally correctly fitted the lower small O-rings on the injector pots - you then messed up - when you took them out again, you got it wrong with the O-ring in the wrong place - it thus couldn't seal the pot - and as its not building fuel pressure, the car just keeps pumping - hence the hydro-lock.  And why it runs with the injector unplugged as its the fuel leaking by feeding the engine - 6hrs work and a messed up engine - for the sake of a bit of vaseline / other lubricant and it would have gone together correctly - and also never fit paper gaskets dry that's why they 1) fail to seal, 2) stick and tear next time round
I think replacing the injectors, and TPS might help, along with 50 years of checking wires. Good luck to you!

GM vehicles of that era would at times suffer from hard start concerns due to a failed coolant temperature sensor. One that has failed with a reading of -40 degrees will lead to massive over fueling of the engine. The O2 sensors of the era were slow to warm up enough to provide info to the ECM. The fact that you were able to leave the engine running while chasing down some parts leads me to believe the coolant sensor should be on the list of possible culprits. I hope this helps you. Keep up the good work. By the way, my Dad and Mom owned one of those and it worked well for them. It did have a slight driveline shudder when operating on 6 cylinders at a steady road speed. Other than that, it was very smooth.

Maybe resetting the computer clears the error codes. Once set, those codes goof everything up. PCMs are extremely robust in their construction; the chances of the computer being "bad" are not great. The computer relies heavily on sensors to tell it how to behave. If the sensors are wonky the computer will act crazy.

Darewreck, ya' gotta remember any oil that's been sitting undisturbed for many years will always go back to it's original golden colar as the particulate that makes it turn black settles to the bottom of the pan. Once it gets hot it will loosen and go right back to black!

Please change the temperature sensor in the 81 Cadillac. A t b I is so simple it makes a carburetor look like alien technology The PCM is not getting a signal from the temperature sensor so the injectors are stunt wide open. That's why it will start after you unhook. The battery and it resets but once it doesn't get the signal, it just sticks wide open.

You mentioned how good the car looked with no rust issues.  I had a '75 911 and a '79 911SC.  The '75 was a rust bucket but the '79 was pristine.  The Porsche dealer told me that about 1977 steel used in cars changed.  They changed the way it was clad which cleared the rust issue considerably.  That's why '80's cars don't generally have huge rust issues like the older cars do.

I just dealt with almost exactly the same problem on a GM TBI. The fuel pressure regulator is built into the throttlebody and if it gets trash in it, That exact thing will happen. If you let it sit, it will work for a little while until it clogs itself back up. It's infuriating because it absolutely acts like the IAC closing off or something. Meanwhile, the computer keeps seeing it run lean, so it opens up the injectors, which will flood the engine until the garbage in the regulator stops it up again.
