The lower injector seals MUST be installed into the grooves on the throttle body, NOT on the injector pilots as you did! Fuel is bypassing the injectors and going right down the venturi! That o-ring seals fuel around the injector to feed it. Placing the o-ring around the pilot WILL CAUSE fuel to leak past the injector and cause the flooding condition you are having.
I‚Äôve used a plywood spacer before. Got me home.
I've been down this road before. With these tbi. It can literally be as simple as putting the o ring on the Injector wrong. 87 s10 2.5. Everytime I turned the key it would just dump fuel non stop. Turns out after fighting for a week or so the o ring wasn't seated properly. After fixed the o ring ran fine. Tbi is a pain

I have had this issue in the past Coolant temp sensor was bad it was telling the computer it was negative 30 something degrees so it would dump fuel thinking it needed it to run. Swap that sensor and it will probably run fine.

Once again, Derek has the patience of a Saint.  Most people would have sent it to the crusher when it appeared to be jinxed.  The brake drum taking off was hilarious! If I recall correctly, these early systems didn't have many sensors.  The primary ones were throttle position, manifold pressure, and coolant temp.  The O2 sensor was just a mixture trim that didn't get used until the engine warmed up.  There had to be something wrong with the fuel system though.  The injectors shouldn't dump any fuel until it starts cranking.  Not sure if there was a port for a scan tool on something this old but that is the easiest way to check the readings on the primary sensors.  The OBD I systems on GM would also flash codes at you on the check engine light if you jumped a couple pins on the connector.  Crude but better than nothing.   Camera man did a good job keeping out of the way and capturing the action.
My hat's off to you for giving it your best shot. I know from experience how difficult it is working with old computer controlled ignition systems that have all kinds of sensors feeding electronic signals to it. I drove an 1988 Corvette for 18 years. For the first few years I fought gremlins throughout the circuit. But then I drove it all over the country and never got left stranded on the side of the road or even a check engine light. I would gut that entire engine compartment and install an old trusty 350 crate motor with a 650 4-barrel on it. Thanks for doing what you do and sharing your experiences with us.

I was thinking of a carb swap as soon as you started messing with the injectors. Thanks for trying,  you are brilliant and hilarious.
Huh, the TBI seems way more simple than I thought. Each injector has it's own "bowl" of fuel it sits in. The diaphragm is the bowl stop filling control thing. Then a pulse of 12V makes the solenoid fire, allowing the pressurized fuel out. Do I have that right? Who knows, but it certainly sounds right and it's really not too different from a carb. Just uses electricity to allow fuel under pressure at the right time instead of air flow/venturi.  Also, that same IAC thing is on my 91. They are annoying to deal with, as even the "factory set" instructions don't help. Took me about 4 hours to get that in a position the car was happy with.
I like you having a camera crew with you. when you get home and after a few cold snacks, pull the motor and install the good old LS

I'm not sure but I think you said the coolant sensor connector was corroded.  High resistance  = low temp.  Low resistance = high temp.  If you unhooked it the computer thinks it's driving around  in Antarctica.  Making it dump gas.

Back in 1980 when this computer system was being develop it was known as the Hal 9000 unit. Good morning Dave.
Manifold Air Pressure sensor (MAP) or coolant temp sensor. Both are dirt cheap and readily available as both were used on zillions of GM engines.  I had an iron duke in a Pontiac 6000 with a single TBI set up.  Insanely reliable setup - put over 400K miles on it before I donated it to be a field car (engine still ran like new).  At one point I had a bad MAP sensor in my ZR-1.  Pulled the unit of the 6000 - LT5 then ran like new again!  Bought a new MAP sensor for $15 and all was well again.  Good luck!
Gut that motor and computer.. Also,  don't say something is frozen...that's for cold use.

It might very well be the computer, they all suffer from dementia (most computers will forget what is in their memory within 50 years, the error is called "bit rot" and how long the memory will survive is "data retention") Also computers are affected by certain forms of radiation, even the little bit that is present everywhere. It can override certain bits in memory creating values that aren't supposed to be there, depending on the capabilities of the computer the value can be 2x larger or smaller. The value difference is likely less than that, but can also be much greater (eg. 16x).

These systems are a lot simpler than you could imagine. The TBI units only really need three essentials to run:  The MAP sensor The Throttle position sensor The Temperature sensor  These are speed density systems. Meaning the fuel mixture is based off the rpm of the engine. The computer references load values (map sensor reading) engine speed (crank position sensor) temperature, and throttle angle to provide the engine with a preprogrammed fuel charge. The oxygen sensor is in place to simply fine tune the fuel mixture further.  All of these systems start in what is called open loop. This means the engine is cold, and the ECU ignores the oxygen sensor readings until a certain temperature is reached. Once the engine reaches near operating temp, the system enters closed loop, and the computer begins to accept inputs from the oxygen sensor to provide a more precise fuel charge.  The way this car was flooding out, and its inability to idle, plus also setting a check engine light, I would focus on the MAP sensor operation and the temp sensor as well. Erroneous readings here can really screw up the fuel mixture.  Also, GM TBI units require a solid 13 PSI fuel pressure to operate and the return back to the tank needs to be smooth and clear of obstructions.  Would love to see this thing get wrinkled out because with the stupid 8-6-4 deactivated, these engines are actually as reliable as any small block.

2:45 Heard a story out of Britain about Rolls Royce. Guy was touring the Continent in his new Rolls Royce. On a back road in Germany the engine fell out of his car. He call Rolls Royce and they put him up in town and a crew came out to assess and repair, hopefully, his car. Three days later he gets the car back. 6 months and he is back home with his car that has been running just fine. Calls the dealer about his adventure and is curious and would like to know how much it cost to handle the engine falling out of his car. The dealer asked him what might he be talking about? He relates his story, whereupon the dealer states with haughty disdain, "Sir, engines do not fall out of Rolls Royces."

1) Put a timing light on it and point it at the TBI to check the spray pattern.  Check it when cranking rich as well as running to see if you notice any change. 2) Use an oscilloscope to troubleshoot.  Put one channel on one injector.  Put the other channel on different inputs at the computer.  (must use a wiring diagram) You will be able to find what is changing and making it go rich. 3) Check the grounds.  Including the grounded pins on the computer. The oxygen sensor will never make that large of different in fuel delivery - a car without the O2 will run rich but not hydrolock rich.  Cars will run well in open loop without using the O2 sensor.  Only MAP/MAF or TPS will cause it to dump fuel like that.  My own guess would be corroded connections.   You are very good all other aspects of cars.  Buy and O-scope and become an expert with the electronics of the 80's and early 90's.  You are bound to have more cars from this era.
Hell, what about ripping everything off that big block 368 that you don‚Äôt need and installing a Holly Sniper EFI system then run a dual exhaust and call it a day? I bet it would turn out to be a pretty decent cruiser.

Wandering if it is O2 sensor since the muffler were clogged it carbon up the O2 so bad,the computer can‚Äôt get a reading.
I had a similar issue with a GM TBI dumping fuel, it was a coolant temp sensor!  So this was on a 1994 K2500, 350.  So the Computer has a simple map of fuel vs engine temp and warming up for emissions.  With only so many bits available, you have to account to at least around 200+ degrees, but you can't have "negative bits", at least in the same file so another another panel of information is stored containing information for "below zero", and depending on how that temp sensor goes bad, it's trying to add fuel and warm up as if it's -200 some degrees out and oxygen is so dense it's liquefying.  At any rate, it was a couple dollar sensor so I figured why not, and I'll be dipped, it worked!!!  I'm not sure if the explanation is true, but that's the one I was told, and it DID fix my problem.
That was pretty funny when the drum came off,that drum was most likely in a hurry to hit the roadüòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ
It would be cool to see a running and complete system. Never seen one.
What an great channel....Dirk and his car adventures!! Love to see it ..each time something new...The rear drum "walk"  was really quite  something.!!! ...did it pas between the camera legs, did I seen that?? ?    In regards to the engine issue... I would think, there is an issue with an injector.. as they are very sensitive for rust and dirt....You can try to attach a small 5 watt lamp to  EACH injector terminal..and check the flicking of the light on both sides, when starting..if  the computer & output  is OK .  Then swap the injectors from left to right...if the problem moves as well.. you  have a fault in  the injector, very simple...and I think it is the issue. They need to be cleaned in a ultra sonic cleaner, while under load, so  open, to get all the dirt out. If the nozzle  of the jet do not move free, it will flood the engine..Like you have seen..it has to open & shut  off 100% correctly... . It is in ANY case for sure a  REAL & HOT  "Go to town rig"..so  very much worth fixing it Derek... The inside is soooo cool!! ...even if it means to knock out the EFI stuff...if things get really complicated... and nail an Edelbrock on it..Go for it mate!  Keep up the great work...Big hug to all of your family ! Best  regards....  Peter ,  Netherlands!

Go through the TBI unit again...I had a similar issue on my 95 Chevy. First I had the 2 top o-rings and metal rings improperly installed and 2 of the lower o-rings improperly installed on the injector. Once fixed, it ran great.

I made a little device that might help you as well. Sometimes I have to test for power in an area I can't see while I'm giving it power. For example you turning on the key while you're trying to see if you're getting power back at the gas tank wire. I wired a door buzzer from a 70's Chevy to a couple of alligator clips so I can listen from the driver's seat if I'm getting power to something. So far it has always worked and I don't have to be in line of sight of a test light.

All the GM TBI cars would flood like that   Turn out that the coolant temp sensor would tell the ECU that it was -1000 degrees out and it would then command 100% duty cycle on the injectors. Ok Hear Me Out LS Swapped Coupe Deville Nice little hot rod
These early 80's GM vehicles had a direct impact on my automotive career. It was hard to charge a customer for all of the time involved to get it function properly. one of the other problems was the quality of parts. getting sensors that were bad right out of the box. The test equipment needed was also an issue. Where I lived they started emission testing of vehicles. So, more testing equipment was necessary. I moved on to an import shop, selling and installing used and new parts. I then moved on to working on to medium duty trucks in the shop and in the field.  that was from early eighties to late nineties, about 18 years.
This is a 42 year old car!!!!!!!
That was a tough load of work, incredible perseverance Derek, and lots of cash.  Why do auto makers scale technology beyond their means, there's a reason why that motor lasted just 64k miles. thanks for the content, this was not easy.

My 81 deactivated V8-6-4's mpg sentinel still worked and showed 8 cylinders all the time
The GM TBI computers almost never fail, I have seen 2 bad ECMs on them in 20 years of messing with them. That being said the grounds GM used to tie the ECM to the engine are horrible at corroding. Corroded grounds act like a bad ECM and can cause all the solenoids to click from inadequate voltage operating them.  Clean the grounds, change out the coolant temperature sensor and MAP sensor. When they are dumping fuel it is almost always the grounds, the MAP or the CTS has failed and that basically makes the injectors flow near maximum flow. Correct all the vacuum leaks. Change the bumm ignition switch as they can reduce the vacuum to the MAP causing overfueling.  If the fuel is dribbling out of the fuel injectors with them disconnected, I gurantee it has a pinched injector o-ring. I always had better luck installing the lower orings on the injectors with a bit of vasoline and gently tightening the screws a little at a time until they popped into place. I had one of these cars I kept up for an older customer of mine for 15 years. It still ran great with the V8-6-4 function enabled and got great highway mileage for a big old boat. By the time he hung up his keys for good the car had over 300K on it and still ran well. Other than that, find you a carbureted 425, 472 or 500 and drop it right into it.  Hook you up a bypass regulator to regulate the pressure down to 5-7 psi for the Q-Jet and let it rip.
After watching this one Derek your patience was beyond incredible, i take my cap off to you sirüëç
Not gonna lie I think this is the only car I've ever seen on the channel that just shouldn't be returned to active service. We commend her for her service.
LS swap it and bring it to the Freedom Factory.
Great attempt! Been working on cars for over 30yrs Rule #1 for any obd1 system when it dumps fuel, unplug the coolant temp sensor for the computer. When they fail, they tell the computer its -39 degrees therefore it dumps the whole fuel tank down it. Then go from there. Would like to see an update on this. Thanks for sharing with us!   P.S. You asked why TBI didn't last. It's a descent option to add injection and fuel trim to an older block as it's basically just a "smart" carburetor. But you can't adjust the fuel trim cylinder by cylinder, so some will always be a bit off unless you have a rats-ass perfect fuel distribution through the manifold.

It could be working properly but the fact that the exhaust is cut and thus causing the o2 sensor to read a ton of oxygen, it's dumping a ton of fuel as it thinks the air/fuel ratio is lean.  Coolant temp is probably still reading cold so it won't enter the official closed loop mode, but if it's anything like the LS generation ecus, they still have some that are programmed to have the short term fuel trims function from o2 sensor feedback when the engine is cold or still in "open loop."

26:30. The power seat transmission is likely not toast. Its just gummed up by the grease. Basically there are some magnetic clutches that engage the gears depending on what movement you want and these tend to stick with old grease. Its an easy fix. I learn as much from the ones you don't fix as I do the ones that work. Thanks!
With regards to the 864 functions, yes there was much trouble with this new technology at that time.  But once this feature was disabled by unhooking one connector, the car would run identical the 1980 6.0 368 cube engine.  I bought a used 1981 Fleetwood 4-door in the late 80s. It had the 864 engine and the 864 function was still working fine at 70,000 in this car.  However, I didn`t like the somewhat rough engine operation when it cycled to the 6-cylinder mode, it was very smooth in 4 and 8 modes but not 6.  I ended up disabling the feature by pulling the connector at the transmission.  You can also bridge the same connection with a paper clip at the fuse box if you want.  I was aware of several people that had these engines and once the 864 feature was deactivated, these engines ran fine.
What should you do with it? Give it to Cadillac Dan for a Christmas present!

I don't comment much, but wow this video was great. I love when the unexpected happens. I saw you struggle with the injectors and immediately thought well, we won't learn about how some of the first mainstream (apart from, I think, earlier Corvettes) fuel injection worked. He'll just get a carb swap, which is understandable. Instead you stuck with it. I love it when people do their best to preserve history, even if that history was full of issues. You have such a unique way of working on cars and as someone who can't see, I love that you take the time to explain what you're doing, why you're doing it and what should, in theory, happen when you're done. I learned more in this 2 hour video than I learned in all of my automotive shop courses in high school. Your knowledge needs to be passed on. Sadly this seems to be a somewhat dieing art. Not sure about anyone else, but hearing those valves slide and click was fascinating to me. Also just weird. The ECU is on the passenger side floor behind the compartment thing. The contacts and connectors always corrode. Pull it off, clean the board side with a WHITE eraser. Give the connector some love too. Inspect the board, look for swelled caps or other burntness.  We used to swap out the intakes with a carburated 368 manifold. I believe I've swapped on 425 manifolds, but not certain. I do know from experience, you Cannot get away with running the TBI manifold with an adapter + carb. It never would run right that way.

Derek, the main sensor on the early GM fuel injection systems used to determine how much fuel to inject is the MAP sensor.  First suggestion is just to unplug it and see if that gets you closer to injecting the right amount of fuel.  Second suggestion would be to replace it.

Mine was optioned a bit differently with the vinyl roof not covering any of the back window and had opera lights (unless this car has had the vinyl replaced with one designed for the Fleetwood Coupe and they forgot to put the opera lights back... Hmm)...  Mine also had a factory sunroof, which could explain the different vinyl roof.  It also had bad trunk struts for the heavy trunklid that had extra weight applied as a faux-continental kit on top of the trunk, which broke the pulldown I noticed this one doesn't have, so my trunk wouldn't be closed most of the time.  It also had a bad climate control that wouldn't turn the fan on, so it was so cold in Iowa winters.  I had one of those little plug in defrosters I'd hold while driving to keep the window cleared.  Oh, and that map pocket is a trash can.

I worked at a GM dealership when this car was new. A big complaint from Cadillac owners with the 8,6,4 system even if it was in perfect order was the continuous incessant lurching and hesitations from the transmission shifting up and down and the torque convertor locking and unlocking while the engine was shifting from 8 to 6 to 4 cyl. modes and back. The smooth rolling Cadillac ride was compromised without any significant gains in fuel mileage.

Looked like a TBI 220, in 1981? Whaaaaaaaat? It's a shame it didn't have an ALDL connector you could short the pins on and read the blinky blink codes.  The only other thing I could think of, and maybe you did it and I missed it, was to unplug the coolant temp sensor and see if you saw any behavior difference.  The newer units I believe "Guessed" what a missing sensor value SHOULD be based on other sensor values, depending on which sensor was out of range.  If "spray-a-palooza" stopped after unplugging coolant temp, you might be able to stabilize it.  I had similar behavior with a Ferd with the "EEEEEEEEEEK 4".  Turned out I was right about the coolant temp sensor, but the replacement made no difference.  Took it to a mechanic, and he replaced the bad out of box sensor, and it purred like a kitten after that.  Would love to take that one off your hands, what a piece of history! (For better or worserrrrrest)

As watching , and seeing something to the same effect. When cranking it over ,and seeing the TBI and TBS act that way the starter was pulling voltage down on the cpu (or what ever they called it) .Then trying to clear codes ,new alternator,pulling off ground to reset,the variable valve switches disconnected ,to all points to a Very Bad Ground issue with the cpu,or the whole ground system. An oscilloscope connected on the input voltages ,then on the outputs should be able to tell if you had a bad ground or severely compromised computer. Get a Fluke meter hook up to battery watch for severe voltage drop . Get an amp meter hook to positive to starter for how many amps it draws ,too much  and the system fails. I read that the cpu runs off 5 volts ,but where is the tap to knock it down to 5 volts. All those cut wires,dash problems ,shorts or faulty ground .It would take a very long time and the engineering schematics to test. Fluke meter,Fluke amp meter always have them on hand. This is theory ,but that car is a basket case. The wires in the engine bay out of the wire loom ,it was exposed to check voltage signals. Taking the negative off and reconnecting makes it seem like a voltage drop problem. The computer resets as it gets its voltage and runs,disconnecting wires the voltage jumps ,computer runs. ( ground on the cpu housing,bad ground on the wire loom,very bad ground from battery,or no ground from battery to on board system). All theory but need schematics.

Man. I hate to see you struggle. I am guessing that the COOLANT TEMP SENSOR is bad. I assume. This car has similar setup as my 1985 Mustang CFI. My car was dumping fuel, wouldn't run properly, even after rebuilding the TBI. Unplugged one injector, it would run, but like crap. Lol sound familiar? Now I replaced both temp sensors, and it runs GREAT! The computer thinks the engine is cold, dumping more fuel like a choke. That sensor corrects the too much fuel issue. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

To me this one seemed like your hardest one ever
Darn it‚Äôs so simple, you forgot to do the O2 sensor preload. Most people didn‚Äôt know but on the 4/6/8 engine it‚Äôs very sensitive to that. Once you install the new O2 sensor you need to torc it to 500 foot pounds then a 1/2 turn. Once that is done exactly use the GM computer reset tool or you can take an open ended wrench, 14mil and lay it from the positive side of the battery to the negative side and leave there till the wrench is a bright red. The bright red color indicates the computer is reset and you can then drive home.
I love that the camera man chuckles at ‚Äúshrek‚Äôs wedding ring‚Äù

The frustration of trying to straight pipe a rusty Cadillac
I have a 1989 TBI C1500, that wouldn‚Äôt idle, unless you put foot to the floor, on the first start up. I remember my professor saying that on a cold start, the coolant temperature sensor is the very first sensor the computer reads until it goes into closed loop with the O2 sensor. Sure enough, I checked the data port on it. It was reading dead hot, so the computer was completely dumping fuel. Looked like that is what you were fighting.

The late 70's 500 cubic inch Cadillac had an optional Bosch fuel injection (8 cylinders only) that was port injection instead of "terminator broccoli injection". It was more advanced and worked better. It was expensive though.  The MAP sensor was built into the ECM which was located inside the car. This 4/6/8 system is way worse. I drove one (a Seville) from Dallas to Lewisville in the mid-90's and it worked fine. I'm glad you found a Coupe. I'd love to have that car. Can't afford a nice earli '70's car any more.

I've been at this long enough to have had success with those awful things. They're a combination of a reliable and commonly used EFI system and some pretty janky crap to try and skirt EPA/CARB standards of the early 80s. It actually works to some degree, but not enough to justify the drivability issues and weird sensations it created in the car, even when it worked at its best. That said, lose it. It's more gimmick than tech. Proper functioning EFI with a healthy mid-displacement V8 should've been able to deliver similar fuel economy, even back then.  That's a really straight car... worthy of a mild Chevy big block or LS swap, for sure... Just swap out the climate control stuff for analog/mechanical controls. It's still GM parts bin stuff all over that car... Almost every stupid digital headache in those Cadillacs has a mechanical/analog equivalent used in another GM product, usually Buick or Oldsmobile that can be swapped out with minor modifications and some smarts...   I'm also fairly certain that you can get the plastic bumper fillers again made from a plastic that DOESN'T digest itself in the sun, which is always nice...  I vote you drag it home, go shopping in the achives, and harvest some new propulsion for that sled... make up for the schitzophrenic V8/6/3/1/7/?/whatever... put some miles on it, actually wear that seat out a bit...

Yet another story of emissions requirements outpacing the technology of the time. The idea wasn't a bad one, but the early electronics just weren't capable enough to do the job reliably. Hell, even today cylinder deactivation still has its issues. The computer's just not the limiting factor anymore.

If you disconnect the plug on the transmission it will only run in 8 cylinder mode only. Make sure the ign module is tight they would loosen up and loose the ground. A little lock tight solved that problem. I had the computer go out and got a remanufactured one from Cardon and never had that problem again. 2:03:08 rear brakes rebuilt.
As a retired mechanic who had to work on these when they were new, I cried right along with Derek. And I'm still drinking, too.  On these cars, it was rarely the computer that failed, it was the multiple, many sensors and their connections. Many of them were vacuum operated (BARO, MAP, etc. )A disconnected hose to the MAP would run it full rich. Bad CTS switch, same thing. Cadillac in those days (actually from 1980 to present) did and does their Quality Control using the customer as their test bed. Very innovative stuff, but halfway engineered, and most of the time, not ready for Prime Time. Another excellent video, and it brought back all the pain. Thanks, Derek!

He gave me the Coles Notes version, but he told me the idea behind the workings and what they did to fix it was disconnect the "brains" and just ran it as a normal all the time V8. The brake drum coming off was hilarious. Then, seeing you laugh as much as I was, that was good stuff.
In 1999, I bought one of these V8-6-4 Caddys from the elderly original owner in Calgary, AB. It had about 60K miles on it. Fleetwood Brougham D‚ÄôElegance, toppermost of the poppermost, completely loaded including the power moon roof, memory seats, and the outrageous $3,500 option real wire wheels. I spent $10K in parts alone doing a complete mechanical rebuild on it. Very comfortable, nice riding car, but otherwise a horrible, spiteful, malicious, soul sucking, unreliable piece of junk. It had constant, crazy electrical issues. I replaced the variable displacement rockers with standard rockers, thus defeating the variable displacement. These cars were still in wrecking yards then, and I had half a dozen of every key component as spares.  I strongly believe the real failing of these cars was GM penny pinching. At one point I had the driver side door right off the car the investigate wiring faults in the hinge area. There are about forty wires in the rubber bellows in the hinge area. I found about seven that had sections of missing insulation. The insulation was brittle, like dry mud. This cheap wiring is, I‚Äôm sure, a significant source of all the electrical gremlins in these cars. I suppose GM saved $4 per car by cheaping out on plasticizers in the wiring insulation. The 368 engine is probably as good mechanically as any 500/472/425, and there‚Äôs no issue with the TH400. The rushed-into-production replacement engine for ‚Äô82 was the 4.1L HT4100, hardly any improvement. Derek, no help is coming. Save yourself, crush that car.

My dad had one of these 1981 8-6-4 Cadillacs - bought used in 1990-ish? - that was modified via a switch attached to the fuse box to always run on 8 cylinders.  If you accidentally - ask me how I know! - stepped on the switch, the normal 8-6-4 would kick in.  It was really noticeable when the engine changed back 'n' forth between cylinders.  My dad had a bad run of GM cars - like the 1984 diesel Olds '98 that blew the engine - and then the transmission, and, when he was younger, the Monza engine that was destroyed by 60k miles.  Later on he bought an Olds Aurora with the Northstar 4.0, which, amazingly was quite reliable.  For a few years after that Oldsmobile we were a Nissan family - all thanks to that "fine" GM engineering.  He's back to GM now, I just hope that 3.6L in his Buick lasts him until the last years of his life and doesn't mess up with the chain guides.

Man, I felt your pain on this one.  For one, something went really, REALLY wrong when this car was in storage.  Gramps either nosed this into a pond a few times, or stored it in an area where alot of water was near/under the car, allowing for extreme condensation.  The rust in that engine compartment tells it all.  The dots of rust in the screws that hold the top of the fenders on.  For goodness sake, rust on the UNDERSIDE of the air cleaner!  Water destroys everything and in weird ways.  It is water that ruined those injectors (if that is what they are called).  I think your poor starter was doomed before there was that load put on it.  The alternator too, all at the same time?  That does not compute.  Water got into everything in that engine compartment.  Add to that Grampy's and friends attempts to fix by yanking out wires and cutting out the gas tank show an amount of tinkering that did more damage and didn't help at all.  Another explanation was that GrampFarty was the kind of guy  that hosed out his engine compartment every time he washed the car, and "let it jus dry nat--rually!!!!!"  It would require a real specialist and some major dollars to bring that thing back around.  I would be shocked if it turned out otherwise.

I would replace the temp sender. That's a pretty common issue with the early gm fuel injection. It can cause the injectors to fire full speed ahead if the readings aren't right. Definitely one of Derek's most entertaining videos. One thing that should not be overlooked is that the problems American auto manufacturers had in this era (70s-80s) were mostly because of the meddling by politicians. GM was a particular target of people like Ralph Nader, one of whose activists was a guy named Bradford Snell who wrote a paper 'American Ground Transport' that caused a lot of political trouble, including congressional hearings. The Roger Rabbit movie was inspired by one of several anti-trust cases against GM.  This disaster of an engine would never have been built if not for government.

Hemi or LS swap lol
I cut my teeth  working as a GM tech back in the 80s.  Several thoughts came to mind about the flooding issue, and I THINK, at 2:06:49 in the video you unplugged a sensor, said it was very corroded and ignored it. After that, it ran pretty decent and ran until you got back from picking up the charging whirler.  You may have temporarily restored connection? The early GM coolant temp sensors were single wire with a white connector.  They are a thermistor, which means the colder they are, the higher the resistance.  So an open circuit, such as a heavily corroded connection would be telling the ECM that it's like -40 deg, and it would really dump the fuel....not that the car would actually run at -40. I know you can't actually check fuel pressure on the old TBI units without an adapter,  but if the pump was high pressure like for  port fuel injection, the regulator may not handle it.  Those pumps unregulated will make around 90 PSI as I recall?  I'm not sure about the TBI pumps.  But a restricted  return line...plugged, bent metal line, kinked rubber line, will make fuel pressure skyrocket I don't think that car used a MAP sensor, but rather a vacuum sensor and a baro sensor.  If you lost the vacuum source to it, it will run rich. I don't think the O2 sensor is causing an issue.  You had to get the engine, and the sensor up to operating temp for the system to go into closed loop. The idle control motor has 2 circuits.  The actual stepper motor that controls the idle and a nose switch the ECM that the your foot is off the gas pedal.  When you're on the gas, the stepper motor extends and as you take your foot off the gas, it gradually returns to idle speed.  They were problematic.  The nose switch would fail and it wouldn't return to idle. I used to take them apart and clean the nose switch rather than replacing the unit Adjusting the plunger just set the minimum and maximum authority,  There should be an old fashioned throttle stop screw on the throttle body.  When it's working right, you can increase the engine speed to about 2k, depress the nose switch and the plunger will retract fully.  Unplug it and let go of the throttle and you can set base idle speed. If you get a chance to revisit this car, I hope these tips help.  It's a pretty cool car, and I'd like to see you make it run sort of the way it's supposed to.  It was a perfect example of GM poorly executing a good idea at the wrong time. It seems the biggest problem with the v8/6/4 was the electronics of the time.  The ECM just couldn't keep up with it and get confused
This needs to be a "to be continued"

The MAP sensor was not very sensitive but the engine (water) temp sensor was very sensitive and could cause that problem. It starts on open loop ignoring the sensors but then goes into closed loop. A bad sensor then becomes the problem.

I think that thing behind the thermostat housing that you unplugged, looked at, said "its rusty, probably dont matter", plugged back in, then it started and ran good, I'm pretty sure thats the coolant temp sensor, I'm not saying its bad per say, but a poor terminal contact could make for erratic readings to the ecm, the low end of the scale is -40¬∞F, a cold start @ that temp requires alot of fuel to fire the engine, see where I'm going here?

With these cars if you disconnect the cylinder deactivation stuff it will run like a normal v8. However it is still just a 368 which was the last cadillac big block. 80 was the first year for that motor. Only the cylinder deactivation and related crap were 81 only. Get 80 parts like carb and distributor and it will be fine

I had this EXACTLY problem on a cheap car with TBI once, every time I switched it on,  the injector would slowly fill the intake up and flood it. I spent hours looking at it! The 8-6-4 6 Litre engine, was offered in 1980 and 1981, the 425 c.i.d from 1977 to 1979 and the 4.1 litre from 1982 to 1986, the  5 litre V8 was std. from 1987 to 1991, in 1992 to 1993, the 5.7 litre, and from 1994 to 1996, the 5.7 litre LT1.

Check the ohms on the injectors obd1 gm cars if 1 injector is out of its ohms it will just the car down no matter what you try it will just keep doing this it can be cold run fine for a few then shut down all over again once the injectors warn up so check cold and warm ohms
Oh my God I love watching your vids. Fire sir! ‚ù§üòÇüî•
I owned one of these back in the late '80s that I bought from a dealer in San Diego, who was selling it for an old woman whose husband had died not long after he bought the vehicle new.  I had been parked in the sun so the lacquer burgundy paint was rather badly damaged on the hood and the trunk.  It had the same white vinyl roof, and exactly the same interior.  The only problem I ever experienced with the 8-6-4 was at freeway speeds with the cruise control on.  It would constantly jump from 8 to 4 and back again because 4 cylinders was just not enough to keep that boat going 70 on cruise control, so it would slow down and the ECM would keep firing up the other four cylinders to get it back up to speed.    An old mechanic at one of the garages I called said that there was a chip or something that you could remove that completely disabled the 8-6-4 routine, and it left you with a cast iron 350 that ran on 8 at all times.  I never tried this, but he sounded very confident in what he was saying.  I'm dropping this comment at the 1:43:30 mark so sometime in the last half hour plus of the video maybe you come across this.  I don't know yet.  But what I'd do in your shoes once you get it back to shop is rip out the whole ignition system and install one of the Holly Sharp Shooters or something like that.  As far as I know, the engine itself is the same as any other 350.  I could be wrong about that but I do remember the advice that old mechanic gave me.  I loved that car, by the way.
The camera person is ice. I could not hold the camera near as steady as they with some of the Derekisms.
Derek! Check coolant temp sensor resistance. Had same issue on old tbi 350 and when it goes bad it defaults to like -50 degrees so it will dump way too much fuel and flood

Sadly, generations going forward are not as willing to digest a man sized helping of muffler dust. Lmao
I had one of these 368's in my '81 Seville that I got from my father. I remember the solenoids for the cylinder deactivation were so gummed up they wouldn't work correctly. I ended up just buying the regular rocker arm bolts from Cadillac and eliminating the solenoids completely. Made a world of difference. Only thing was when it tried to switch into 6 cyl. mode you would get a very quick dip in acceleration  that only lasted about a milli-second. The only thing the solenoids would do is change the pivot point of the rocker arm so they would pivot on the tip of the valve when activated, pretty neat actually. Good luck with it.

I had a 350 TBI Chevy truck and it  was dumping fuel out of the injectors real bad like that, turns out the return line was clogged. I got the return line free'd up and it ran perfect. If fuel can't return to the tank it gets dumped right through the injectors

Just watched the video and having wrenched on GM cars and have had a lot of experience with TBI injection across different manufacturers. One thing has always been true, If it‚Äôs running Rich to the point where it‚Äôs even flooding out, it is always the engine coolant sensor that the computer reads. I seen you unplug it and look at it and say that‚Äôs corroded and you plugged it back in and you went to start the vehicle and it started. It ran great for just a while. I think you have either a bad coolant sensor, or a bad connection to the coolant sensor. Would love to know if you ever get it running what it was that ultimately fixed it. GM vehicles of that era were also known to have ECM problems and GM put their ECM‚Äôs right below the heater car. You can also just unplug the ECM, and it will generally run in a limp mode.  Love the channel and my boys watch the channel also and they do learn a lot from you.
The old GM Toilet Bowl Injection was actually incredibly reliable. I‚Äôve worked on probably 1000 vehicles with it on it over my nearly 20 years as a mechanic and they rarely have issues. I think the only reason they get so much hate is because certain people would rather have a carburetor because they don‚Äôt understand fuel injection. That and they were installed almost exclusively on malaise era vehicles (or relics of that era) that made 1/2 the power they should make, even though that really had nothing to do with the TBI.  The problem with this car is probably the coolant temperature sensor. That‚Äôs usually what makes them pour fuel immediately when cranking. If it is corroded or just bad/disconnected, the ECM will think that the engine is sub-freezing (usually -40) and just _pour_ fuel in because that‚Äôs the only way the engine would actually start if it were truly that cold. The O2 sensor has zero effect on the fuel injection until after the engine has been running for a few minutes AND the coolant temperature sensor is greater than a certain temperature (my memory says 160F). Even then, its adjustment ability is limited to about 25% of the total amount of fuel being injected, which is _not_ enough to make it flood that badly. Cars will typically run OK even if they‚Äôre running 25% rich (they just get horrible fuel economy). If there is any fuel coming out of the injection without the engine running or cranking, it‚Äôs because it‚Äôs leaking. Could be leaking past the injectors that were seized up and probably damaged by being jabbed with a screw driver or a split o-ring around the base of the injector.   The cylinder deactivation is a different story. That‚Äôs a disaster now, there was basically zero chance that it would work 40 years ago.
I had a buddy that owned one of these cars and he loved it. It ran great, until it didn't anymore. He took it to the dealer and they told him that it would be some astrnomical amount to replace the PCM. They offered him a good amount for trade-in and he took it.

Pretty good chance that car has a bad coolant temp sensor. When the temp sensor goes bad or the computer doesn't see a coolant temp signal it defaults to cold start fuel. Basically the computer is acting like it is -40 F and adding extreme cold start fuel.

These 368CI were taken out by some dealers and these were retro fitted with either of two engines you could get a Oldsmobile 307 CID V-8 or a Gas 5.7L 350 BBL V-8 as an option. i have nothing bad to say about those early tbi (toilet bowl injection) engines. i've had more problems with the ignition control modules and fuel pumps than the tbi unit itself. i think i've only replaced one set of injectors. if you keep the vacuum leaks plugged, delete the EGR, and give it a free flowing exhaust and snip the o2 sensor, it'll run a touch rich but it'll atleast stay running at a light. almost as reliable as death and taxes. i parted a 95 chevy truck out that had over 350k miles on it, cracked transmission but that tbi motor fired right up every time. my 95 gmc c1500 has 281k on the original tbi 305. it was beat on before i got it 8 years ago, and i have a heavy right foot. been through 4 transmissions and 3 junkyard 10 bolt rear ends, but the 305 is bulletproof. i have a 350 vortec im building for it, but the 305 is still kickin. if it aint broke dont fix it.

I have changed many of those Injectors a long time ago.  Never have I ever touched the allen screw.  I think that was for setting the pintel travel/fuel volume on a injector flow bench at the injector manufacturer. Wrong fuel pump.  Those run very low pressure, most of the other cars at the time ran higher pressure.  Fuel pump over pressuring the injectors causing them to stick open, and even when it does run, it's way rich.   If you adjusted the fuel pressure regulator down to where it actually ran a bit, the pressure was likely still too high.

I'd like to see this thing brought back to working with the TBI.  It is very possible but maybe this isn't the channel for it.  Full diagnostics were possible through the climate control display.  Codes, engine values, etc.  You really need to know what the computer is seeing or thinking to diagnose fuel injection.  Aside from the V8-6-4- thing, this is (early) GM TBI, which is about as simple as it gets for fuel injection.  The later ones were quite simplified as far as emissions stuff.  The TBI unit itself is made by Rochester.  They ran until about 1995 in trucks.  A little browsing on Rockauto reveals that you can buy anything you need to get this running right.  Including an ECM.
Ya know whats funny about these revive and drives the ones that look easy end up being the hardest to get running most of the time lol on another note i cant imagine why this was only a one year only engine it seems fine.

Having owned a 1981 Sedan DeVille with the 368 V8-6-4 from 11k miles to 85k miles; if they're taken care of and not molested; they are much better engines than given credit for.  I had no problems with the engine itself other than a cracked exhaust manifold (noisy, but replaced) and a broken free fuel tank baffle causing intermittent stalling (new tank installed), those were the only issues I experienced from it.  It always averaged about 17.5 MPG.  Not a fast car, but plenty of torque for pulling a fully loaded down car up mountain passes at highway speeds with no problems at all.  It had the burgundy velour interior just like in this video, but a two tone burgundy/cranberry paint scheme.  An absolutely beautiful car I'm sorry I let go.

I laughed...... I cried......... And then,  memories came flooding back. My favorite Cadillac was the '80- '85 Eldorado. And I had a plethora of them. I always got them when they were on their way to the junkyard; and I would get them cheap. I had a 4,6,8 and it ran great for a long time without any issues. It musta been the lucky one üòÇ.  Wait until you get to play with the 4100. Most people didn't take it back to the Dealership to have the camshaft replaced due to it being "too soft". NAPA sold a kit to replace the camshaft,  timing chain,  and lifters. I had 4 Eldorado Biarritz's  with the 4100 engine and they were great for me, fuel mileage especially. BUT VERY IMPORTANT was to change the antifreeze every year; and ONLY USE DISTILLED WATER for mixing. I never had overheating issues or head gaskets go bad.  I'd love to see it run with all the electro-didgicals from the factory,  but that would probably be expensive,  lol. Definitely would make for a great long term winter project for someone üòÇ.

On these True Broccoli Injections, the computer only commands to open the injectors,  fuel pressure is not controled by the computerbox, so your excess fuel issue is a strictly "mechanical" issue. And for the idling, the idle air valve is controlled by the computer, that is taking in account engine temperature and thecreading onbthe map sensor(sensor has a green connector and a vacuumhose on the rear of the tbi unit. We have tugged a few of the 4,6,8 engines as well as the 4.100's or what ever they were, even a couple oil burners, and it's a fairly simple swap to a 5.0 or 5.7 TBI ENGINE from any truck or similar TBI powered car for a donor. It already possesses the in tank fuel pump, and everything related there for the swap. But unlike the g body cars these don't seem to have multiple motor mount patterns in the frame like a g body has, so always had to drill "major pain" or just hot glue some Chevy frame mounts. Been 20 years almost so details are foggy, but they weren't difficult swaps.

I had a beautiful 1989 Mercedes 300 CE. After it left me stranded three dozen times I figured out all of the electronically controlled fuel injection equipment was finicky crap and devised a carburetor adapter to a 350 CFM carb with a low pressure fuel pump, and distributor adapter to a vacuum advance type Dodge slant six dizzy. Tossing the fuel pump, accumulator, fuel distributor, sealing off the injectors, goodbye to the IAC, TPS, the EZL, catalytic converter and a half dozen other worthless pieces of junk I got the thing running fine. Sold it and bought a Toyota, which has never needed any attention outside of normal wear items.
A bit ironic you finally get a car with a really nice interior and rust free body and all the issues are with the engine.   Doesn't seem fair.   Likely too much corrosion some where, all the rust is under the hood.   Far too nice a car to not get it running but I have no idea what you should do with it.

What a battle! Fun episode!
Ah, yes. The Cadillac V8-6-4. Great idea, but the technology of displacement on demand and cylinder deactivation wasn't quite there yet. IIRC, it was an electro-mechanical system that would deactivate cylinders by "disconnecting" rocker arms from selected cylinders. There was a "fix" when issues developed where dealers would bypass the system and run the engine on all 8 all the time. And the TBI (throttle body injection) system is actually very simple, and works well when folks who don't know what they are doing keep their booger-hooks off of it! I had an 87 K5 Blazer with the TBI 350 and it ran flawlessly. Had to sell it, unfortunately, to make a couple house payments during tough times. I currently have an 84 Corvette with the CrossFire injection TBI system, and it works just fine. I rebuilt the TBI on a neighbor's 87 Suburban 350, and it was surprisingly simple, and really woke that thing up as well as helping with MPG on that behemoth. Take care, Derek, and good luck getting that old beauty going again! I've just started watching, so time will tell....
It sounds like it could be the temperature controller sensor, had a Chevy pick up running just like that . Dumping fuel down the throat. Changed it out ran like new
A guy's got a hunch that the pump is pushing 60ish psi instead of the 12 it needs maybe?
Hate to say it but I appreciate the fact that you showed so much struggle and a fail. Personally I'd like to see all the crap stripped off, new injection kit thrown on and convert it to a 4x4 mud wagon! :D

In late 1999 I bought a 1981 Cadillac DeVille Flowercar conversion....basically a Cadillac ElCamino with a stainless steel bed. I thought it was pretty cool, but I had similar issues. Mine also had the 6.0 liter V8/6/4 and it ran well enough to use as my daily driver.....but it did run poorly, it sputtered, it randomly died, it was hard starting afterward. Several suggestions came to me from various sources...mainly the TPS and the crank sensor. I had considered a carb swap but on my way home from work one day, the engine died mysteriously and the computer caught on fire. I was told that the cars did not have a sufficient ground. I put a new one in it but I had to replace it as my daily as I needed a reliable A to B. I read that the variable displacement could give a 10% increase in fuel economy. Since I was seeing 17mpg on the hwy, that meant I might see an additional 1.7. I was underwhelmed with this engine. I had also considered a late 70's Pontiac Trans AM engine as it should bolt right up to the Cadillac Turbski 400. I even thought I might put the shaker scoop through the Caddy hood. Since the car did its funeral home duties in Boston, before I bought it, it had some weight reduction underneath and I decided to let it go. I think that even if the 6.0 is returned back to factory spec, it still is plagued with design flaws that keep it from being a proper powerplant for a GM flagship.
For all that effort with the 8/6/4 engine, you could have done a used LS swap, giving it more HP, torque, reliability, better fuel economy and much simpler to work on.
Good effort,  can't win them all
The fuel pressure regulator (when leaking) will allow fuel to be pumped into the intake through the internal vacuum port where you can't see it, filling up the engine.

I owned a 1981 Seville with the V8-6-4. Pressing and holding  hotter and colder  hvac buttons gets you into the efi diagnostic system. In there you can check the injector pulse width,  as well as adjust the fuel mixture.  Get yourself a shop manual from somewhere and get the TBI working properly.  Those systems can be quite reliable.   As far as the V8-6-4 system, with it disabled it got 14 mpg on the highway.  Enabled, and on 4-cylinders, it got 24 mpg.  Other than being truly gutless on 4 cylinders and surging between 4 and 8 on hilly terrain, the system always worked flawlessly.  I put over 200,000 trouble free miles on it before selling it to a guy who put another 150,000 on it.   I recommend leaving it stock and leaving the V8-6-4 enabled. I did rig up a switch on the dash to disable it for when driving on hilly terrain, but rarely disabled it.
Hold the hot and cold buttons on the ac down at the same time and turn on the ignition and the screen should go to diagnostic mode

On 1980's FI engines, I just unplug sensors until it runs decent, then replace the last sensor I unplugged. There's also a simple way to test the signal through those early sensors, but unplugging is faster.

That's a beautiful Cadillac! It would be nice to see the problems sorted out with this one. Even if it involves an LS swap with possibly a Holley EFI system.  When I saw the fuel dumping into the engine, my first thought was that one or more of the o-rings may have been dislodged from the injectors. Fuel actually goes around the injectors before being injected into the engine, so it's important that the o-rings are seated properly between the injectors and the throttle body.

Welcome Derek, to the Malaise era! Just slide behind the wheel, and be enveloped in that sense of ennui and hopelessness unique to early emissions era cars. Try unplugging the Temperature sensor located on or next to the Thermostat Housing. Leave it Unplugged and start it.  GM Was notorious for these going bad in the 80's and early 90's from my experience. They will "Pour the Onions" when stuck at a cold start temp. And then if it runs normal with it unplugged, replace that and you're good to go. It's a free try before spending $$$ on a new computer
The only time I had problems with a tbi it was a bad ground.
If that engine had backfired, the MAP sensor is most likely shot
I love watching your channel, Derek!  You are soooo SILLY!!! LOL The part with you fighting with the muffler had me cracking up!!! LMAO
Those TBI systems were VERY sensitive to flooding IF the coolant temp sensor was faulty OR reading lower than the actual coolant temp.   I used to get phone calls back in the late 80s-early90s when the weather here in the north would get REAL cold and all my relatives TBI cars were flooded and wouldn't start.  They'd crank on them forever, flood the crap out of them, then call me.  I'd make the rounds to their houses and open the air cleaner lid, remove the one or two injector wire clips, and it would instantly fire up and run for 10-20 seconds. When it would finally start to run out of the loaded up fuel, and start to stumble from lack of fuel, I'd quickly stick the plugs back on the injectors, and it would be good to go.  I did that a few times a winter for a number of years before those cats were gone and SMPFI was the standard.
I had a 72 Fleetwood with a 455 Quadra jet.   I also had a 84 DeVille and I replaced starter, alternator, plugs,  and those injectors.   It was a pain to work on but it didn‚Äôt have the cylinder shifting garbage.  I put a lot of miles on it and there was nothing like cruising it down 95 at night running 90 with the windows down and the radio blasting.  It was like a boat.  Do a hard turn and you know it turning by the tires squealing then a half second later the car starts turning.
I couldn't turn it off and save some for later.  Such a nice looking car, interior especially.  Unfortunate the electronics are caca.

Just think how fast a tweeker would have had that cat out.  And need a coolant temp sensor, that's step one of every TBI troubleshooting session.  And they are sometimes bad new out of the box.
Turn the screw on the regulator counter clockwise to increase the fuel pressure. GM had those dialed down so low for economy and emissions reasons, it will run a lot better increasing the pressure to around 15psi. The crossfire injection on the 82 Collectors Edition Corvette has a similar setup and fuel pressure was always too low on those units once they start to age. Also if the coolant temp sensor is malfunctioning it will put the injectors in max dispense.

I worked on a lot of the cars of this era, and the injectors definitely shouldn‚Äôt drip! Should have a nice spray pattern, only when cranking or running. Pretty cool old car though. A guy will need a little luck with that fuel system! üòÖ And yes, I worked for a shop that modded these to run full time on all 8. Even independent shops were doing it. The O2 sensors won‚Äôt affect engine performance at all until the vehicle enters enclosed loop mode. It has to be warmed up fully so I doubt that it was  having any effect on the engine running while you‚Äôre trying to get it to run for just a little bit. I am guessing that those injectors are just leaking badly into the throttlebody. The fuel pressure regulator was the last piece you messed with. Not normally serviceable if I recall correctly. This is the kind of set up that you would definitely need to go back to the fuel system service manual to get it right.

üëçüëçüëèüëè
I had an 87 full size GMC Jimmy with the 5.7 liter TBI V8. That TBI system was never very good. Mine always took a while to fire up after sitting, I think it tended to flood itself too. I got a mildly built 350 for it on the cheap when my friend upgraded his Blazer to a stroker and it never would run on the TBI. Interestingly, it would flood out like that and would only run if you disconnected one of the injectors. I swapped computers with another truck and no difference before or after the engine swap. I ended up putting a carburetor on it and it ran great. It was an easy swap since the TBI fuel pump was compatible with the carburetor. I wish I still had it, it would be worth a bunch now but I had to sell it when I moved across the country. It would have cost a fortune to drive at 6MPG.
..and engineering idea, created in the marketing department..simple..
From what I can recall working with all the TBI business the engine management was based on engine vacuum signal to atmospheric and manifold pressure sensors, the fuel pressure regulator, coolant temperature sensor, and the throttle position sensor. The AIC was the fast idle for cold starts, which didn't affect the Oxygen sensor until the engine warmed up. The over rich condition is likely to do with three elements; the coolant temperature sensor, weak springs in the fuel pressure regulator, and partially hanging fuel injectors. The fuel pressure regular should run at about 12 to 16 psi, which can be adjusted, while running a pressure tester in line. Hung injectors are likely the biggest culprit in this case, but that darned coolant temperature sensor will only make things worse if the TBI isn't near spot on.  The ALDL, under the dash, can also be shorted to read off the ECU faults from the management system. There is a lot going on with these early fuel injection engines that slips past our notice.

Temp sensors being shot will often read super cold to those old Delco computers. I had an old Saturn that would DUMP fuel. Couldn't figure it out, until i got live data out of it, and saw -40¬∞ temp. Now, it could run in that temp, but it would be a good amount of fuel. But, since it was 76¬∞ out, it would idle, but bog like crazy when you gave it any throttle.   Once i got the sensor swapped it ran like a sewing machine.

As I recall having the same problem as you had on the Caddy I nearly pulled all my beard hair out just to find out it was a Low engine temperature sensor left front of the engine . It was a small sensor that supplied computer was a low temperature reading for start up and warm up which acted like a cold start valve . When that sensor goes bad the engine floods and nothing you can do to stop it unless you can fool computer into running but the low temp sensor always catches up . when the engine temperature drops and the sensor is faulty . There is a low engine temperature and a high Engine temperature sensor .

Painful to see you fight this. I never heard you say the word Coolant Temp Sensor, if it's open and reading - 40 it'll dump fuel. Map sensor can cause issues. Raw fuel dumping in the TBI could be from you thrashing the 2 injectors around and also not applying lube( I use petroleum jelly) to the upper and lower o-ring's when re-installing the injectors. You also later messed with the fuel pressure regulator without knowing what the real pressure is. As you found out, you can't get answers by guessing. To start with- Short the A and B terminals in the ALDL connector under the dash to read(blink out) the codes. Actually test the fuel pressure, 81 GM TBI is supposed to be 9 to 13 PSI. And then you have that 4/6/8 crap, delete it. GM's OBDI TBI is very simple. Don't put a ECM in it unless you are absolutely sure its bad, chances are it's good.

I'm a master certified auto technician with 30 years experience.  I specialize in electrical/electronics. I worked for a GM dealership for 20 years and won the GM mark of excellence award for electrical/electronics and HVAC diagnostics for 6 years in a row (every year the dealership participated in the program). I would say that you HAVE to have a problem in that Throttle body Derek.  Maybe the o-rings weren't installed correctly on the injectors when you put them back in? Possibly a higher pressure fuel pump than the TBI needs like you mentioned as well. I can tell you this for sure, the ECM isn't pulsing those injectors just turning the key on, so if it's leaking fuel through the injectors before you crank the engine it's NOT the ECM causing it.  So, when it is running and the ECM is pulsing the injectors, you're still getting excess fuel as well. Don't just scrap the TBI setup and throw a carburetor on it.  This thing could, and likely will run good after you address those injector/FP issues. On a side note, regarding the computer code clearing,  the process you were trying near the end of the video is to clear the codes from the Automatic climate control module, not the engine control module.  If you want to discuss this or other issues you have with it lmk and we'll figure out how to get in touch.  Thanks for the entertainment and keep up the great work!
Cars were required to have either automatic motorized seatbelts or front airbags starting with the 1987 model year, there were a few companies that offered motorized belts as an option before that, but not Cadillac. By the mid '90s, the either/or option had been removed and cars were required to have airbags no matter what, and nobody ever liked the automatic belts in the first place, so they went away at that point.

On this one ,I'm egitimately concerned about Dereck's health.... that's a LOT of carbon Monoxide he's huffing through this WHOLE video.
In 1983 I graduated high school and I went to work for a shop that did automotive electric and air conditioning, plus installed spot lights, sirens, emergency light bars, etc... for police, security ambulances etc... this shop in downtown Los Angeles had been in business since 1932 in the same location.   We worked on a lot of Cadillacs old and new.   The 1970s and early '80s were so terrible to work on. Just like what Derek is going through, hoses, sensors, tubes, relays, everywhere.   That electronic climate control unit in the dash not only was your heat and ac controls but it was also the computer interface. There was a way to push the buttons to get codes from the computer like an early version of an OBDII reader. Lots of window motors replaced, lots of starters and yes you had to drop the exhaust system to get access to the starter, alternators, power antennas, ac compressors, frozen expansion valves, God help you if the heater core was leaking and needed replacing, high beam floor switch had a plug that was purposely made to melt from the factory and it would make your high beams flash or stay on, I must have cut out and bipassed 500 of those connectors. The horn pad on the steering wheel would wear out being a very thin piece of foam rubber that smashed down and would let the horn contact continually make contact with the steering wheel causing the horn to honk nonstop or sometimes only when turning the steering wheel. You would hear a customer coming from a couple blocks away. Hahahaha  I could go on and on about how terrible GM was in those years.

I admire  you for taking on this revival. I work on gm cars professionally and early tbi can be a pain   Some points of note , if only one injector is going full beans if be suspicious of a shorted injector ( internal), injector  harness , or a bad ecm.   If 1981 had live data with a scan  tool ( ive used gm tech 1 on at least mid 80s cars)  id want to  know what the block learn was, basically early fuel Trim. Id want to know if the computer knows its running rich. Because  that could lead me to a bad sensor/ sensor wire or ecm. If also want to know what codes its throwing.  If its capable  of operating  in open loop id unplug the o2 sensor and run it to see it it runs better on backup fuel tables based off of other sensors  Id make sure your map sensor,  coolant temp sensor and other sensors that effect  fuel trim are in good working order.   I heard rumors that 1981 caddilac v864s got deleted and that some were even converted back to a carb setup due to the trouble they had  And honesly at this point youre reviving  it not numbers matching restoring it. Carb and head swap with older caddy 368 v8 even a engine swap ( ls.... or big block chevy.) or do a modern efi setup with holley   But anyway derek much admiration with what you do out! Im more of a quadrajet or modern efi guy and if i knew you were in Springfield id of gladly tried to help   with the electro digitals üòÑ

Try replacing the coolant temp sensor before you condemn it totally. One last cheap thing to try. Could be dumping fuel because it thinks it‚Äôs -20 at all times.
Most likely a bad coolant temp sensor. Telling the computer it's -40 out and just dumping fuel.
I would try new coolant temp sensor meaning one for computer. If it thinks its really cold out it will give alot of gas to it.  I have more experience with Lincoln or Ford cars and on they seldom fail if cars coolant was maintained.  Other things can do it like o2 and while that was not the primary issues it was bad or old and degraded definitly as well. That car may not have a o2 heater. Ford didn't have o2 on the tbi cars so probably gm didnt. If it doesnt have an 02 heater it will not nake it run rich cold because o2 has to heat up to work.  You can also unplug o2 and rule out if its problem.  What else can make it run rich is map/barimetric sensor. I had do that on my Lincoln mark vi. It ran better than that Cadillac but was smoking black and getting poor economy and stalling at lights.  Check its vaccume line. It will run like shit it its broken or cracked or sucked shut. Check sensor vent thst its open and no one capped it off thinking it was a vacume leak(assuming Cadillac is configurd same).  That made my Lincoln run pig rich.  The air charge temp sensor in the manifold can affect mixture. Not sure it would to this extent but they are very cheap and can and did carbon up.  Other things at least on  throttle body injected known as CFI in Fordanese. They dont like weak alternators or batteries that font hold a full charge. They dont like bad grounds. In fact its wise to add a few extra grounds.  Have decent battery cables. Make sure there are no vaccum leaks and that means anywhere.    The Lincoln has all new sensors over past 8 years execpt I disabled egr and un plugged its solonoids  and cooler. It runs better than with egr closed all the time. The injection is reliable and ut gets 20 to 25 mpg suburban and hwy. Its smooth.  This is a fine car. That is a fine engine too. Cadillac 368 is a smaller bore of the 425 and 500. They ruined them in 82 with a horible 4.1 engine that would fail prematurely and had no power.   Back in the mid 80s people sold these cheap. I knew a guy who had 3 with this engine he got very cheaply and they ran beautifully with the v864 disabled.  Throttle body inhection in the old Ford community has a bad name. It is sort if an automotive dead end. People didnt learn it. It didnt put out codes from 80 until 84. And in 86 or 87 it went away with the beloved and tuneable and well supported in the aftermarket multiport replacing it. That said throttle body injection was smooth and efficient and worked well. If you reason it out its basically like multiport but with map sensor instead of mass air flow.   Love all the shows.  You should revive a 80s Lincoln.

I know exactly what the problem is only because I've ran into this problem before. The ecm is reading -40 coolant temp, in the case I ran into it was the ecm. The only way to know is plug into it with a scanner. In the case I ran into it was a cross fire injection in a Vette, the wire resistance checked out okay all the way to the ecm in the coolant temp sensor circuit.

A bad Coolant temperature sensor will cause all the problems you're experiencing if it's feeding the ECM a -39 degree value.  Very common problem in that era.

I worked as a Service Writer for a Chrysler/Plymouth dealership back in1984 (K-car days... I didn't stay there long!).  We had a customer who was a Dentist that had bought a new Imperial in 1983.  It had the 318 with fuel injection, and it was very important NOT to touch the accelerator until after it started!  If you pressed the accelerator-- even a little bit-- before cranking, it would NOT start.  Needless to say, the dentist was not happy, and he told all of his doctorial friends about it.  The dealership finally got permission from the regional service manager to remove the fuel injection and retrofit a carburetor.  The price tag for the swap was almost $2000!  One of the coolest things I saw there was a couple of Chrysler sedans (E-Class I think) that had been special ordered for the local FBI office.  They had the Turbo 2.2 engine, which was rated at 146bhp while the base 2.2 was rated at 72bhp!

The fuel pressure tester goes inline at the fuel filter if its like all other TBI chevy trucks 87-95. Theyre incredibly reliable in trucks, i cant say the same for Cadillac. But if fuel pressure is too high it will push past injectors on these because the regulator cannot let off enough fuel pressure. Here we are over 40 years later and GM still can't seem to get the cylinder deactivation thing right, yet they still keep on producing them. Everyone that currently owns an '07 - '14 Chevy/GMC truck or SUV with a 5.3L or 6.2L engine has taken steps to disable cylinder deactivation either electronically or mechanically because the AFM lifters are going to collapse/fail and allowing it to continue going into V4 mode will only make that happen a lot sooner.

This reminded me that Cadillac had a problem (sorry...I don't remember just which one it was) that had a 24 point factory 'diagnostic tree' to diagnose and I had several cars come in that had been to multiple dealers without them finding the problem.   Step 18 was to check a ground for good connection...problem with that was that ground needed the entire dashboard removed to access!   So naturally the dealer mechanics all skipped it and...you guessed it...that was the problem that fixed the cars.   GM cars of that period were hateful things to work on.

Oof!! The worst Cadillac engine EVER. The best thing to do with those (outside of replacing the engine) is to go in and disable the cylinder delete function in the ECM. Between temp sensors and manifold air pressure (MAP) sensors, these would keep a guy busy just replacing parts. Add in the flawed engineering that allowed it to keep supplying fuel to the offline cylinders until they went active again, and flooding them with raw gas, and you have a recipe for disaster.üíÄ The best cure for these is replace the engine with an old reliable 472. They don't get as good of gas mileage, but they're rock stable and basically trouble free.üòâ

Best episode in a long time. I laughed so hard. I say crush it. üòä
I have a 1988 Dakota with a Holley TBI on it. When it works, it's great, when it doesn't it's a nightmare like this.  Early TBIs like this are super sensitive to vacuum leaks, exhaust issues and bad sensors. I had a problem with mine where it would die if you tried to accelerate, it took a lot of troubleshooting to figure out it had a bad O2 sensor.  My TBI is just as complex as this one with vacuum hoses going all over the place, as well as vacuum actuators on an external block. I had to tear the entire vacuum system out when I got the truck and replace it all, because it was full of all different size hoses from years of bad patch repairs, as well as duct tape to try and cover holes. It hasn't given me much trouble since, and that was over 8 years ago.  There's only really two options to fix this thing. The first is to tear literally every hose and wire out and redo everything from the beginning. That thing has obviously been jacked with considerably. The second would be to tear it all out and put in an aftermarket EFI system or a carburetor. I'd personally go with the aftermarket EFI system because I hate carburetors. I've rebuilt enough of them to not want to touch one again. They just don't work well with modern ethanol based fuels.  As for those fuel injectors, they just need to be replaced. The water likely internally corroded the precision bores and parts, causing them to hang. I had bad injectors in my TBI when I bought the truck and they dumped fuel just like yours did. They are a pig to get seated in correctly, but it saves a ton of headache dealing with bad injectors.

On TBI injectors, usually the screw on top changes the flow rate, it sets the end stop for the armature and thus the maximum solenoid stroke. There are two adjustments that are usually factory set, between the two they set the injector flow rate and the offset time (opening time - closing time). I‚Äôm not sure if you got that top screw in the right place but if the injector is constructed like most TBI units I‚Äôve seen, the fuel flow might be off if it isn‚Äôt set right.

How did Derek not rip that engine out and install a carburetor 350, just saying.
To fix a tbi issue, it takes patience. It cant be forced. Start with the easy fixes first; check for codes from the bcm, then get a dvom and check each sensor, replace the bad ones, check all the connections from the bcm, they can get oxidized and crusty over time. The car will run with failed O2 sensors and rarely will the bcm fail. Check the bcm for water damage and you can use a lcr meter to check the capicitors. Thats where I would start.

Never in my life have I seen a brake drum fly off a car like that.
I had a 1982 Coupe DeVille with the HT4100. That and the 368ci V8/6/4 almost put them out of business. I also had a 1980 Coupe DeVille with this same 368ci motor, except 80 was the only year you could get this motor with a 4bbl carb and without the displacement on demand system, unless you ordered a commercial chassis (limo/hearse). They also received the 368 with a 4 bbl and no cylinder deactivation. They sold the 368 from 80-84. These were actually awesome motors if you can find them with the 80/ commercial carb engine, or remove the DOD. They're actually a de-bored and de-stroked big block. Same block as the 425/472/500 engine. I've seen them with 350,000-480,000 for sale, never rebuilt! The longest trip i took mine on was about 325 miles, it surprisingly returned 18.5 mpg with a 4bbl 368 and TH400 3 speed! Anther useful tidbit is, the Cadillacs with the 368 were the very last passenger vehicles to leave the factory with a turbo 400 transmission! After this, they were only produced in the pickups. Every 368 has a TH400 trans. I would take this engine over the junk 4.1 any day. The HT4100 was an aluminum block with cast iron heads, they loved to eat head gaskets. The 82 I had with the 4.1 was the most gutless car I've owned in my life! I've had 4 cylinders that would walk all over it. I used to travel from home to college on I90, and there was a huge valley near Lewiston, MN. This valley is about a mile down and back up, and has a 3rd truck lane. I used to hit the bottom of that valley going 75-80 and floored the old caddy. I would be lucky to be doing 65-70 at the top of the hill with it still hard on the floor. I would also fill the radiator on a hot day, and drive that 80 mile drive to find the water level had dropped in the radiator about a foot lower. It never leaked anything either, it was sucking it all through the cylinders. It somehow never overheated though, so I just kept filling it and driving! The exhaust would actually gurgle at times it sucked up so much antifreeze!
Hubcaps look like Oldsmobile hubcaps for the Royale
That was a 2 hour and 20 min ass kicking you took! Can only imagine how many hours it was real time! I applaud you for your effort sir!
OMG talk about having patients - the issue with computers and electrical connections over the years is corrosion and resistance and these systems stop working properly.  Early TBI systems were not good  I speak from experience as a Automotive teacher for a decade between 1981 and 1991... when these new systems were just coming out.  And as a Heavy duty  (Diesel Mechanic) since 1977 before teaching I understand  fuel injection both mechanical and electrical and they are not easy systems to diagnose ,or cheap to repair add to that electrical connections that are suspect and you have real fun.

One thing that makes no sense to me, is that you pour some oil or tranny fluid into the vehicle first, then pour the honey into the jugs so it "pours quicker".  It takes the same amount of time to pour the honey into the jugs as it does into the vehicle anyway, so where do you save the time?  Either way you have to wait for the honey to pour out of the jug into SOMETHING, either the vehicle or the other jug.  I even said that in one of my vids where I watch all y'all do that and I told my viewers it makes no sense.  You STILL gotta wait for the honey jug to empty either way.

I think you might have a leak in one of the injector seals. The fuel fills in around the outside of them, so if the o rings leak at all it will leak out pretty bad when the fuel pump is running.

That is a one year only vehicle. I have an 81 Fleetwood, it now has a 425 from a 77. You're going to love this car. Big 12 bolt differential, and a th400. It's indestructible. A 500 bolts right in, in case a Cadillac out back In your stash needs to hand over a heart. Enjoy it.
These 'variable displacement' cylinder deactivation engines are a waste of time. It's the engine's internal friction that determines how much fuel it uses doing down the road. This is why a truck with a turbo V6 uses as much fuel towing a trailer as does a truck with a regular V8. Deactivating cylinders only makes the remaining cylinders burn more fuel to counter the friction of the whole engine - including the inactivated cylinders.
Strip all the crap off the engine and add a carburetor.
Removed the injector pin screw. He pushed the injector pin with the screwdriver. To free it. Put the screw pack in. Wrong adjustment. The pin cannot close completely and uses too much fuel. Just a wild quess.
