I had a 1979 Cadillac Eldorado with a 350 Oldsmobile engine and it was a great car. It was a Florida car with low miles and the mechanic that owned it couldn't get it to run right, something with the fuel injection. I got it for $500 rust free , low mileage, clean car. So, I pulled the fuel injection manifold off it and bolted on a two barrel manifold and carb off a 350 Olds with a mechanical fuel pump that I bought from the wreckers for $50.  A day later I drove it by the mechanic I bought it from and he couldn't believe it was running perfect üòÇ I drove it for 5 years without a problem. That car could go through 2 feet of snow without a problem üòÇ My first front wheel drive vehicle ‚ù§

Dont know what all the drama on the TBI unit was about.That unit looks almost identical to the one thats on my 1991 5L Firebird Convertible.The injectors themselves are pretty cheap and basic.Ive cleaned mine a few times and honestly TBI is more simple than tuned port (which uses more injectors thus more potential problems) . Now, power on TBI vs. tuned port? Well, if kept clean ,my untouched/modified 5.0 will roast the tires in circles which is enough for me.Maybe not quite as good as TPI but far less components to present more problems.And yes, I said 1991 convertible.Truly exists, just low production #'s .Ive owned it for the last 28 years. Only major problems ive ever had were that horrible electric fuel pump replacement (I refuse to cut a hole in my car above the tank therefore you have to drop the exhaust and tank),basic water pump and radiator replacement.Ya gotta be careful on removing the plastic clips that hold the wires on the injectors cause gas over the years can make the plastic clips brittle and break.

The V8-6-4 system used a mechanical system of levers to deactivate certain cylinders at the rocker arms. It was controlled by a woefully underpoweredmicropprocessor that left the system hunting for the right setting, much like a transmission hunting for the right gear. My grandfather had one and returned it after a few months. He bought a Lincoln and never looked back.
I took my driving test in a 1981 Eldorado with that crappy engine in 1990. Even back when they were less than 10 years old they never liked to idle right. Ours had the V4/6/8 (Eaton variable displacement system) disconnected too and it would buck and surge like there was no tomorrow. However, I think age has done in the ECU on this one. I would be willing to bet that the ECU board has failed electrolytic capacitors on it and will need to be recapped. This is a frequent problem with older electronics since the electrolyte dries out over time and changes the capacitance. Capacitors are used to smooth out voltage spikes so with them drying out and dying, the computer gets erratic signals. However, because this is GM, there is hope. While this engine may have been one year only, the GM TBI system was not. So it is likely that the computer and sensors are shared with multiple vehicles and all you would need to do is swap the PROM chip to another computer with the same part number. The even worse 4100 HT Fuel Injection used in the 1982 DeVille, etc. would have had a similar system as would all manner of disposable FWD GM products of the time. There are also ECU rebuilders who can fix them as well, but you would need to find someone familiar with this 42 year old system. Then there are also lay people like myself who dabble in old electronics who may be able to figure it out by trial and error.
I,v been workin on cars all my life..I,m 65 now and I must say the 81 Cadillac was pure poison...üòÇüòÇI threw in the towel on 3 of them over the years...When they stop run,in right they never seem to run right again..Nice try bud..Hard to win with the 81 Cadillac and I ain,t kid,en ya...üòÇüòÇ

LS swap time!
Back in 1981 I went to work in a Austin Cadillac-Oldsmobile dealer and did until 1984 so I know a few things about this car. The engine block was aluminum and you could kick one across the floor if it was bare. They used to say it wouldn't make a boat anchor.  Awhile after this the standard engine was a V-6 if you can believe that. One other interesting thing is I did couple hundred  or more .make readies on these. Almost every one had the wheel covers stolen and the L/R vent widow broken out and had to be replaced. They came into Houston on a train and that is when they would get stolen.  I got paid 2.5 hours for every make ready one I did plus the glass replacement. One year just before Christmas I must have done 30 of these. Nice check that week.  I have a lot of stories from that time period and Cadillacs. Remember the first computer controled systems came out in like 1979 Oldsmobiles. Red Adair bought all his crews Eldorado's from that dealer and he turned them all back because when they got anywhere near the Houston ship channel they would die from radio interference. The whole engine idea was ahead of it's time and the electronis's were not. You see the same valve modulation today on some cars.
34:32 distorted sneeze made me laugh too hard

You need to flush that tird!!!!!!

I was 17 years old in 1984 and I purchased a used 79 Eldorado diesel with 27K on the odometer. I traveled from Freehold N.J. to Atlantic City and needed good fuel mileage. That car lasted about 6 months before blowing the crank through the bottom of the engine. King Cadillac and Sons under threat of a lawsuit traded me out of the 79 and traded me for an 81 Fleetwood Brougham with the V864 with only 18k on it. That car lasted 4 Months. To this day I still own my 1976 Eldorado Convertible with no issues. I have always said 1976 was the last year for Cadillac. They have been going downhill ever since.

36:12 üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ
It's old enough that you could put a carb on it with out being on the wrong side of the law. So why not. GM had big dollars to throw at the concept and gave up on it. You know you can make a normal GM V8 run and drive. We could all use a car that would still run after after an Electro Magnetic pulse from a nuke going off. That basically means a car with zero electronics. Points condincer and coil ignition and a carburetor. If you want one that the radio would work in we are talking a radio with tubes in it and a vibrator power supply and an actual vibrator not the solid state replacement. A generator with a mechanical voltage regulator will survive an EMP an alternator might not because of the diodes and the electronic voltage regulator.

I fixed mine by screwing in the idle air control rod all the way in then adjusted the curb idle screw to 900 rpm to compensate...it runs very slight rough till about 100 degrees engine temp then smooths right out and runs like a dream...I changed the idle control motor the tps was changed by mechanic but not properly seated so you cant set it right. I worked on this for over a month when mechanics suggested crushing it and it has been running pretty damn good over a year now. I do have the service manual and read every forum post this processed worked for me when everyone said it wouldn't.

The strange thing is.... the system DOES work!  Whatever GM did was nearly a functional system but I'm sure the accountants won every argument.    In the early 2000's, an electronic genius friend of mine bought one of these for his mom.  We all thought he was crazy as we all thought these cars were garbage.  Well, he went through every single system in that car; cleaning contact points.... replacing every capacitor, resistor, IC chip with MODERN (at the time) pieces.  It took him about 6 months but when he was done.... Oh Mylanta... that was probably the nicest running V8-6-4 Cadillac EVER.  His mom loved the thing and drove it until the early 2010's.... when the rust finally began to win.  I believe they still have it though. Last I heard, it's still in their barn because while the body is literally falling off the frame, the engine/trans combo still runs like brand new.

I had the same problem with a 91 k2500  with a TBI. the dump of fuel is the temp sensor (not sending unit) when they go bad it tells the computer it is -80 degrees and adds extra fuel .replaced mine and worked perfect.

Carb swap
Derek, thank you for the entertainment that you have provided all of us over the years. I hope you and your family have a wonderful Christmas. Not sure if this helps but I have had a couple of different gm TBI vehicles, neither were an 864 system though. Both vehicles had major fueling issues exactly like the caddy and both were solved by replacing the engine coolant temperature sensor. The sensor on both had failed in a way that they were reporting extremely low temps to the computer, around -50F. The computer was demanding an extremely high injector duty cycle and would flood the engine. Not sure if you even plan on working on the car again but I hope if this comment finds you it helps you out. Good luck on your next adventure. Always looking forward to your next video.

When you took the fuel  injectors apart. And took the adjustment nut out of the center of the in jectors and screwed it back in To the the injector Pintels, which are what meter the fuel and go up-and-down in the silenod which is the fuel injector. Thay   Have to be adjusted to a set point if they are too tight or too loose. They will stick or just pour fuel out of the injector

Why didn't you just put 2 new injectors in it as well as a throttle position sensor and temperature sensor for the computer.. TBI is the absolute easiest to work on.. I'm actually surprised you no nothing about them. I live in Canada next door to Detroit.  I couldn't get the two injectors here in Canada anymore for some reason. So we had one auto parts store that actually brought in all there parts from the states. They got me my two new injectors and rebuild kit. I couldn't believe how simple the TBI system is.. there's basically two injectors and a factory fuel regulator. That's it.. no floats or needles or pilot jets or anything a carb has or tons of wiring you have with the new injection systems

2:03:10 was hilarious. I peed a little laughing so hard.
I worked for Cadillac as a district service manager when that car was introduced. In pre-release service meetings, it was well-known from the very beginning, that the 8/6/4 was planned to be a one-year-only engine. The big problem was the early Delco electronics. The MAP sensor was calibrated with too-close tolerances. If the engine hic-upped (backfired) it would shut down. There was no repair except to replace the MAP sensor. The bigger problem was replacement stock was the exact same part, and it took GM a while before an updated unit could be supplied. Dealers would disconnect the 8/6/4 feature, running it as an 8cyl only. The press had a field day. I inspected a limo in West Palm Beach, Florida, that the owner wanted all the interior chrome replaced. Someone had discharged a tear gas device inside the car that caused the damage ( the interior chrome pieces came from different suppliers, so it was impossible for all of it to be defective) and I denied the claim. It turned out the limo was owned by the owner of the newspaper 'The National Inquirer" (famous for stories like 'I got pregnant by an alien, etc.) They went on a HUGE hate campaign, smearing the vehicle, which only threw fuel on the fire. Those were tough times to be a Cadillac District Service manager.

Time for a LS swat
Ah, the ole 368c.i., 6 liter, V8-V6-V4 disaster of a Cadillac engine.   It was G.M.'s first foray into cylinder deactivation in order to gain MPGs.  The primative computer system would "decide" when the engine's load was low enough, and then it would deactivate 2 of the 8 cylinders to become a 4.5 liter V-6, and then when the engine's load was even less, and the car remained at a steady cruise for long enough, it would drop two more cylinders and become a 3.0 liter 4-cylinder.   The engine would deactivate the cylinders by using oil pressure directed to a special port going to the lifters, and it would then allow the lifter to detach from the pushrod cup, and allow the lifter to still ride up and down on the cam, but NOT move the pushrod up and down, and hence the valves on that cylinder would not open and allow that cylinder to function.   Compression would still happen on that cylinder, and the compression would act like a spring to balance out the engine and attempt to keep weird vibrations and misses from being felt by the driver, but with no fuel in that cylinder it would not fire.   The deactivation system was very troublesome on these vehicles back in the day, and with MOST of these cars, the system ended up disabled by G.M. because it caused too many issues.  You can disable the system, and the engine will remain in 8 cylinder mode all the time, by simply disconnecting the black wire that connects up to the transmission, right above the pan rail. This black wire tells the computer when the transmission is in 3rd gear, and controls when the deactivation happens. By disconnecting this wire, the ECU will never receive the signal that the car is cruising in 3rd gear, and then it won't attempt to deactivate cylinders. It will NOT activate the check engine light, or throw a code either. You can disconnect the wires going in to the tip of the valve covers to deactivate the system also, but then you'll get the engine light and code.  Good luck with that beast, Derek..ü§ô üçª
At 1:47 minutes. This is why Derek doesn‚Äôt like to work on the digical cars.
"Whiter than Celine Dion concert". LEGENDARY. ü§£ü§£

Hmmm..I was a wet behind the ears tune up technician starting out in '84 when these cars were just aging out of their dealership lives and moving into the realm of independent garages...saw more than a few of 'em. Spark plugs are actually pretty simple on these, you jack 'em up and go in thru the wheel well with a 3 foot extension.. The 4-6-8 had a piss poor rep and a lot of jokes were made, but I honestly don't recall them being any worse than any of the other barges GM was hustling in that era.. I moved on from the tune up shop to a local Pontiac/GMC/Toyota(?) dealer in '87, one of the bodymen there had one, and it lived well into the nineties, had a few hundred K on it as I recall..rode like a cloud, handled like an ore freighter..

I was in the NAVY with the guy that invented and sold Cadillac the patents for that motor! They paid him $13 million for it. Then their "engineers" completely redesigned and ruined it. It was a solenoid controlled valve and timing system (Genius Stuff!) but not originally designed to shut off cylinders selectively, and hence RUINED among other mistakes or over complication....

The displacement-on-demand system was disabled on most.  My mom's friend Di had a big old white Biarritz with the same system.  It was an extremely smooth car and super luxurious with a great ride but the cylinder deactivation system was herky-jerky or just didn't work.   The TBI system is NOT the same as the later GM V8 TBI's, but it's much better than the early system used on the early fuel-injected Sevilles.  A four-barrel will swap on easily or better yet a Holley Sniper EFI.
I owned two 81 Cadillacs back in the day both were 864 and both had the computer clipped so they stayed on 8 cyl  and honestly they both ran amazing after that and I still miss both of them thirty years later.   I hope you get to enjoy that coupe as a going to town rig asap
Despite this 8-6-4 system being such a disaster when it came out, the concept was so revolutionary that all automakers (including Zee Germans) ran with the idea and it is extremely common even in today's cars.  Once it was perfected, it was very common to get upwards of 30 mpg out of a V8 in a full size car.  I give GM a lot of credit for trying, but a lot of grief for rushing it to production too soon.

Fun fact from the what the heck is wrong with this TBI archive in my brain. The wiring to the injectors matters, JUST enough to screw with you. Had an OBS chevy that REFUSED to rev over 2500RPM, ran perfect, but flat wouldn't go over that mark. I checked for governors, every sensor imaginable, then I got the bright idea that someone put the injector wires on backwards. Sure enough, backwards, swapped them and it ran perfect.

I don't know if this is similar to how the computer-controlled carburetors worked in the 1980s, but I remember that my 1981 Buick Electra with the Olds 307 and a computer controlled Quadrejet would dump fuel when the O2 sensor was plugged in because the catalytic convertor was missing, and they designed some of their systems to rely on the backpressure that the convertor provided. When I put a convertor back on, it started fueling much more reliably.

Here's a crazy fun fact. In 1993 when the north star v8 was at its height, it had nine on board computers and twelve hundred pounds of wire and a fuselinks
Those automatic seat belts were a result of the government mandating a passive restraint device. GM mostly got around the automatic belts by attaching the upper mount of the seat belt to the door frame so that you could enter and exit the car without unbuckling the belt. Now a days air bags check the box for passive restraints.

The 368 was a good engine and there was a simple-ish wiring way to make these constant V8s. The 368 stayed with the limo and commercial chassis' a few years more, but just as a 6.0, without the cylinder deactivation. It was a good engine, just a smaller version of the 425, which in turn was.... blah blah historical stuff.  I had two models with the V8-6-4, one in an bronze Eldo with red leather, it was made a constant V8 and then it was fine. I really liked the activision-style technology in these cars and they are not as awful as people say (just not always reliable) Just like many old electronics, you have to know both the mechanical and electrical, plus tricks with the climate control buttons and paper clips.  The Oldsmobile in this case, (or other GM) wire wheel effect hubcaps used on a Cadillac but from another marque were always a sign of someone who didn't want to pay for the factory Cadillac wire hubcaps but wanted "the look" after they realized they looked alright.  Not that anyone cares, but anyone who can repair old radios or electronics can repair the computer, it's normally just a bad resistor or capacitor that needs to be soldered in. They can be repaired and are as dependable as any 1980s tech.
The TBI is simple and crude EFI. It is pretty simple to rebuild. I am surprised you haven't modified them. I only like it to convert the TBI trucks to Olds V8 power.

Your commitment to struggling on your own, even when you have another person there is commendable.
The thing that most people don‚Äôt really understand about this engine- it really is a great engine at the base of it. Bones derived from the venerable Cadillac big block, of which I believe you have a few 472 examples like old Betty White.  You mentioned the gas crisis, which is why they put this modulated displacement wizardry on this engine, along with making it fuel injection. Well, you can stop all that wizardry from working by clipping one wire. I have mine switched underneath the dash (yes it still works). But when those wizards started failing, Cadillac knew that this system wasn‚Äôt going to be able to hold them over until the next generation of Cadillac power was ready. Which is the MAJOR reason why they ditched it, along with all of the bad publicity. If they could have stuck 368‚Äôs, 425‚Äôs or 472‚Äôs in all of em, I‚Äôm sure they would have. But EPA standards wasn‚Äôt gonna let them do that. So they rushed development on the 4100 and had it ready for 1982. Talk about a disaster!  4100 did FAR more damage to Cadillac‚Äôs reputation.  In retrospect, they should have just done a Ford and shoved a SBC or Olds in it and put emissions crap on that- like they did for Oldsmobile, Buick, Pontiac, etc. But Cadillac at the time prided themselves on having exclusive power trains that could not be found in any other GM product. They gave up around 1986 and started shoving the Olds 307 in them (RWD Brougham models- the rest of the lineup got downsized drastically in 1985 or 1986.) So there‚Äôs a ‚Äúshort‚Äù historic timeline for ya.
Still can‚Äôt beat a Lincoln!!
